description: MCSA Windows 8 (70-688) Over 80% of computers run Microsoft Operating systems [reference]. As a result, the Microsoft Certified Solutions Associate is one of the first steps for those seeking to start a technical career. The MCSA: Windows 8 covers topics that are “must know” for anyone responsible for deploying, maintaining and supporting Windows desktops in a corporate or enterprise environment. Most people know how to use Windows in a home environment. However, there are many features under the hood that are designed for environments with a large quantity of computers. The MCSA dives in to those and gives the learner a whole new toolbox for ensuring their computing environment is functional and stable.
name: MCSA Windows 8.1 - 70-688
subtitle: Supporting Windows 8.1

episodes.description: MCSA Windows 8 (70-688) Over 80% of computers run Microsoft Operating systems [reference]. As a result, the Microsoft Certified Solutions Associate is one of the first steps for those seeking to start a technical career. The MCSA: Windows 8 covers topics that are “must know” for anyone responsible for deploying, maintaining and supporting Windows desktops in a corporate or enterprise environment. Most people know how to use Windows in a home environment. However, there are many features under the hood that are designed for environments with a large quantity of computers. The MCSA dives in to those and gives the learner a whole new toolbox for ensuring their computing environment is functional and stable.
episodes.title: Overview of MCSA Windows 8.1 (70-688)
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,003 --> 00:00:05,818
[SOUND] The 70-688 exam

2
00:00:05,818 --> 00:00:13,333
covers supporting Windows 8.1.

3
00:00:13,333 --> 00:00:17,956
It's the second step, and really, the,
the last step in obtaining your MCSA for

4
00:00:17,956 --> 00:00:18,700
Windows 8.

5
00:00:18,700 --> 00:00:20,140
Now remember the MCSA,

6
00:00:20,140 --> 00:00:24,550
that's the Microsoft Certified Solutions
Associate And it's designed to serve

7
00:00:24,550 --> 00:00:28,120
as that, that mid level certification for
somebody who's going to going to be

8
00:00:28,120 --> 00:00:33,580
working with desktops in a large or
enterprise business environment, right?

9
00:00:33,580 --> 00:00:37,900
For home users, small office,
home office type deployments,

10
00:00:37,900 --> 00:00:41,720
the technologies that we learn in the
MCSA Windows 8 are usually not practical.

11
00:00:41,720 --> 00:00:44,250
It's a little bit overkill for
small environments, but

12
00:00:44,250 --> 00:00:47,760
if you're dealing with hundreds or
thousands of desktops, we learn about

13
00:00:47,760 --> 00:00:52,800
a lot of things in the MCSA for Windows 8
that is very useful and very practical.

14
00:00:52,800 --> 00:00:56,990
Now, keep in mind that supporting
Windows 8.1 is the second exam.

15
00:00:56,990 --> 00:01:01,920
You should start with the first one,
which is the 70-687,

16
00:01:01,920 --> 00:01:05,240
and that one's gonna kind of move
us along on the certification.

17
00:01:05,240 --> 00:01:07,440
So, let, let's take a look at
that track before we get too far.

18
00:01:09,030 --> 00:01:11,920
The MCSA, the Microsoft Certified
Solutions Associate, there,

19
00:01:11,920 --> 00:01:14,500
there's actually a number of different
tracks that are inside of there

20
00:01:14,500 --> 00:01:16,130
depending on what you want to do.

21
00:01:16,130 --> 00:01:18,460
So, for example, if you want to
learn about server technologies,

22
00:01:18,460 --> 00:01:22,870
they've got the MCSA for Windows Server
2008 And Windows Server 2012.

23
00:01:22,870 --> 00:01:26,030
Those focus on the server side,
and while there is a little bit of

24
00:01:26,030 --> 00:01:30,880
client activity in there, the exams
are really focused on the servers.

25
00:01:30,880 --> 00:01:35,280
On the desktop side, there's the MCSA for
Windows 8 and the MCSA for Windows 7.

26
00:01:35,280 --> 00:01:38,260
And, these again are for
businesses that are being,

27
00:01:38,260 --> 00:01:40,980
that are deploying large
quantities of Windows machines and

28
00:01:40,980 --> 00:01:44,570
they need to be able to manage,
maintain and support them.

29
00:01:44,570 --> 00:01:47,050
Now what we're covering is the MCSA for
Windows 8.

30
00:01:47,050 --> 00:01:48,188
And if you dive into that,

31
00:01:48,188 --> 00:01:51,830
you'll see that there's basically
two exams that make up that track.

32
00:01:51,830 --> 00:01:54,590
The first one is the 70-687
that I mentioned a moment ago.

33
00:01:54,590 --> 00:01:59,330
That's configuring Windows 8.1 and it
focuses on getting Windows 8 installed or

34
00:01:59,330 --> 00:02:02,270
deployed in your environment and
getting it up and running.

35
00:02:02,270 --> 00:02:05,090
In 688, we take that same knowledge and

36
00:02:05,090 --> 00:02:09,140
now we say how do we keep
things running nice and smooth?

37
00:02:09,140 --> 00:02:11,958
But its hard to keep things running
if you didn't get them running in

38
00:02:11,958 --> 00:02:12,707
the first place.

39
00:02:12,707 --> 00:02:14,360
So that's why the 70-687 is first.

40
00:02:14,360 --> 00:02:18,385
You can take them out of
order if you want, but

41
00:02:18,385 --> 00:02:21,250
if you're learning about this,
it doesn't make sense.

42
00:02:21,250 --> 00:02:25,470
You're taking the, the second part of
the exam first, but if you already have

43
00:02:25,470 --> 00:02:27,660
the knowledge it doesn't really
matter which order you take them in.

44
00:02:27,660 --> 00:02:30,510
So Microsoft doesn't care what
order you do them in, but

45
00:02:30,510 --> 00:02:33,680
you typically do want
to stay with the order.

46
00:02:33,680 --> 00:02:36,880
All right now the 688 exam is
packed full of good information.

47
00:02:36,880 --> 00:02:38,500
It can be a little misleading though.

48
00:02:38,500 --> 00:02:40,000
If we take a look at like 687,

49
00:02:40,000 --> 00:02:44,960
and we look at its exam, it's divided
up into seven different areas.

50
00:02:44,960 --> 00:02:48,910
If we find those down here, we'll see all
the different areas that are covered.

51
00:02:48,910 --> 00:02:53,510
And they all take like 10 to 15% of
the exam, except for remote access and

52
00:02:53,510 --> 00:02:56,360
mobility, which is 15 to 20%.

53
00:02:56,360 --> 00:02:59,300
When we take a look at 688,
it's a lot different.

54
00:02:59,300 --> 00:03:04,080
The 688 exam is only divided into three
sections and each one is weighted for

55
00:03:04,080 --> 00:03:05,660
about a third of the exam.

56
00:03:05,660 --> 00:03:09,510
So it looks like a smaller exam,
but it is not.

57
00:03:09,510 --> 00:03:11,630
Each one of these are just larger topics.

58
00:03:11,630 --> 00:03:14,580
The amount of knowledge is about the same,
so don't underestimate it.

59
00:03:14,580 --> 00:03:16,810
Don't think that this is a small and
easy exam.

60
00:03:16,810 --> 00:03:19,760
It's actually one of the more
difficult exams that Microsoft has,

61
00:03:19,760 --> 00:03:23,050
because it covers a lot of technologies
that people aren't familiar with.

62
00:03:23,050 --> 00:03:26,070
In Windows 8 there were a lot of new
troubleshooting technologies that

63
00:03:26,070 --> 00:03:26,720
were introduced.

64
00:03:26,720 --> 00:03:28,340
And, you've gotta learn them, right?

65
00:03:28,340 --> 00:03:30,980
That's part of staying up to date.

66
00:03:30,980 --> 00:03:34,210
So if we look at each of these, the first
one is supporting operating system and

67
00:03:34,210 --> 00:03:36,090
application installation.

68
00:03:36,090 --> 00:03:39,210
Well we did operating system and
installation, or

69
00:03:39,210 --> 00:03:42,980
application installation, in the 70-687,
why do we see this again?

70
00:03:42,980 --> 00:03:45,505
Well it's supporting it,
troubleshooting it,

71
00:03:45,505 --> 00:03:48,255
handling issues that may
arise as a part of it.

72
00:03:48,255 --> 00:03:52,505
So this is much more of a ongoing
operation than the original deployments we

73
00:03:52,505 --> 00:03:56,095
saw in the other one, and you'll see some
of those new technologies jumping out,

74
00:03:56,095 --> 00:03:58,890
like user experience virtualization,
right, UEV.

75
00:03:58,890 --> 00:04:02,430
Not a lot of people have worked
with that because it's fairly new,

76
00:04:02,430 --> 00:04:05,970
so these are some of the things that
have been kind of, kind of added in,

77
00:04:05,970 --> 00:04:07,680
that we've got to take the time to learn.

78
00:04:07,680 --> 00:04:10,730
And you'll also see the Windows Store and
cloud apps.

79
00:04:10,730 --> 00:04:13,520
A lot of Internet-based technology
is being brought into this.

80
00:04:13,520 --> 00:04:20,400
So definitely a, a different angle of, of
approaching the same topics from 70-687.

81
00:04:20,400 --> 00:04:23,610
The second section is supporting
resources access and so

82
00:04:23,610 --> 00:04:27,935
we start diving into some advanced things
that can influence sharing resources,

83
00:04:27,935 --> 00:04:30,195
you know, files, folders and printers.

84
00:04:30,195 --> 00:04:33,875
We'll talk about DNS security,
ways to ratchet that up, remote access,

85
00:04:33,875 --> 00:04:34,785
and, and so on.

86
00:04:34,785 --> 00:04:38,980
You'll notice how all this is kind of
lining up with what was in 70-687,

87
00:04:38,980 --> 00:04:39,960
just going a little more advanced.

88
00:04:41,270 --> 00:04:45,849
And then lastly we get supporting
Windows clients and devices,

89
00:04:45,849 --> 00:04:48,960
which is really a catch-all section.

90
00:04:48,960 --> 00:04:51,790
It goes through quite a few different
steps of troubleshooting and

91
00:04:51,790 --> 00:04:55,220
isolating problems, and how to correct
them, and getting things up and going.

92
00:04:55,220 --> 00:05:00,130
So from things like, the boot manager and
how to analyze stop errors all the way

93
00:05:00,130 --> 00:05:04,440
through mobile devices and
even compliance, policy enforcement.

94
00:05:04,440 --> 00:05:06,740
So there's some really neat things there.

95
00:05:06,740 --> 00:05:11,480
This last one really starts to dabble
into the server side of things and

96
00:05:11,480 --> 00:05:14,470
how we can use servers to
manage those Windows 8 clients.

97
00:05:14,470 --> 00:05:17,800
So it really does serve as that
bridge into Windows Server 2012.

98
00:05:17,800 --> 00:05:23,335
There is also a,
a section on Windows Intune which is a,

99
00:05:23,335 --> 00:05:28,120
a cloud based management solution that
not a lot of people have worked with.

100
00:05:28,120 --> 00:05:29,256
Well it's on the exam.

101
00:05:29,256 --> 00:05:31,849
You need to get exposed to it and
understand it, if for

102
00:05:31,849 --> 00:05:35,951
no other reason then to determine whether
or not it's right for your organization.

103
00:05:35,951 --> 00:05:39,580
All right?
So the 70-688, it covers a lot of stuff.

104
00:05:39,580 --> 00:05:43,690
It is a, a big exam and
it's a lot of new stuff for people,

105
00:05:43,690 --> 00:05:45,470
even if you were certified
under Windows 7.

106
00:05:45,470 --> 00:05:48,750
There's just a lot of new things
that have been added since then.

107
00:05:48,750 --> 00:05:50,850
So it is, a bit of a challenge.

108
00:05:50,850 --> 00:05:51,400
Right?

109
00:05:51,400 --> 00:05:52,950
You gotta hit the books and study hard,

110
00:05:52,950 --> 00:05:55,690
and make sure you learn each of
the concepts that are in there.

111
00:05:55,690 --> 00:05:57,710
And that's what our show's
designed to help with.

112
00:05:57,710 --> 00:06:01,740
So in our 70-688 show, we take all of
those topics and we break them down into

113
00:06:01,740 --> 00:06:05,040
episodes that we can cover it and
make sure that you understand

114
00:06:05,040 --> 00:06:07,930
the technologies and are able to
implement those successfully on the exam.

115
00:06:07,930 --> 00:06:12,090
Now the 70-688 exam is just like
every other Microsoft exam.

116
00:06:12,090 --> 00:06:14,140
It's a hundred and
fifty dollars to take it and

117
00:06:14,140 --> 00:06:16,940
you take it at
a Pearson VUE Testing Center.

118
00:06:16,940 --> 00:06:19,360
Pearson VUE has centers
all over the world, so

119
00:06:19,360 --> 00:06:21,680
you can likely find one very close to you.

120
00:06:21,680 --> 00:06:27,550
You can go to their website,
it's www.pearsonvue.com, that's V-U-E,

121
00:06:27,550 --> 00:06:31,140
and if you add a slash Microsoft to the
end you will go right to Microsoft's page,

122
00:06:31,140 --> 00:06:36,620
you are going to locate a testing center
near you and sign up and take the exam.

123
00:06:36,620 --> 00:06:40,982
When you successfully
pass both the 70-687 and

124
00:06:40,982 --> 00:06:45,160
70-688 exam,
you'll be awarded the MCSA Windows 8.

125
00:06:45,160 --> 00:06:46,660
It's a great certification to have.

126
00:06:46,660 --> 00:06:51,850
It shows employers that you understand
how to deploy and maintain Windows 8 and,

127
00:06:51,850 --> 00:06:55,380
it gets you prepared to be ready for the
next version of Windows that comes out.

128
00:06:55,380 --> 00:06:56,980
So when Windows 10 comes out,

129
00:06:56,980 --> 00:06:59,780
you've already learned the bulk of
what's gonna be on those exams too.

130
00:06:59,780 --> 00:07:01,460
So it is a great certification.

131
00:07:01,460 --> 00:07:04,100
Really kinda pushes you along
in a general direction.

132
00:07:04,100 --> 00:07:06,080
Now if you're just getting
started out in IT,

133
00:07:06,080 --> 00:07:10,760
the MCSA is not really a starting
out certification, so for you,

134
00:07:10,760 --> 00:07:15,770
you might wanna start with, CompTIA A+ if
you've already got computer knowledge.

135
00:07:15,770 --> 00:07:18,620
If you don't have computer knowledge
you might want to start with CompTIA IT

136
00:07:18,620 --> 00:07:23,700
Fundamentals or the Microsoft Technology
Association, the MTA certification.

137
00:07:23,700 --> 00:07:26,100
In there we start with Windows
7 at a basic level and

138
00:07:26,100 --> 00:07:28,870
cover things like installations and
basic support.

139
00:07:28,870 --> 00:07:30,190
Not very high level.

140
00:07:30,190 --> 00:07:34,260
If you've got even, even a handful
of months of experience working with

141
00:07:34,260 --> 00:07:39,110
computers you might find the MTA content
a little bit, I'm going to say, boring.

142
00:07:39,110 --> 00:07:41,670
It's not that it's boring, it's just
that you already know the content.

143
00:07:41,670 --> 00:07:42,210
Right?

144
00:07:42,210 --> 00:07:45,092
So, for you, you move up,
you go into the MCSA.

145
00:07:45,092 --> 00:07:46,370
All right?

146
00:07:46,370 --> 00:07:50,910
Now what many people chose to do is to
do the MCSA for Windows 8 as a client.

147
00:07:50,910 --> 00:07:53,980
And then also do the MCSA for
Windows Server.

148
00:07:53,980 --> 00:07:57,440
And that's a great idea because
you get the best of both worlds.

149
00:07:57,440 --> 00:07:58,980
And by understanding the server and

150
00:07:58,980 --> 00:08:01,780
client technologies you can integrate
them better in a workplace.

151
00:08:01,780 --> 00:08:03,690
So that makes you a more
valuable employee.

152
00:08:03,690 --> 00:08:05,890
Not just to your company, but
to your coworkers, right?

153
00:08:05,890 --> 00:08:06,650
You can.

154
00:08:06,650 --> 00:08:10,110
Properly deploy solutions that
are effective and stay running, and

155
00:08:10,110 --> 00:08:11,620
that's really the goal
of an IT technician.

156
00:08:12,840 --> 00:08:14,780
All right, so,
if that sounds exciting to you,

157
00:08:14,780 --> 00:08:16,860
sounds like what you want to learn,
then you're in the right place.

158
00:08:16,860 --> 00:08:21,250
Stay tuned, our episodes for
70-688 are starting here in just a moment.

159
00:08:21,250 --> 00:08:24,330
if this is the wrong place for
you, you know, it's no big deal.

160
00:08:24,330 --> 00:08:27,150
Jump over to one of the other
certifications that I suggested.

161
00:08:27,150 --> 00:08:30,290
For the server side, you're looking for
the MCSA Windows Server so

162
00:08:30,290 --> 00:08:35,300
those start with the 70-410 exam so
you wanna go and find that show.

163
00:08:35,300 --> 00:08:37,890
If you're starting out
a little more basic than this,

164
00:08:37,890 --> 00:08:41,970
then you want to check out the CompTIA A+
if you have some experience, or

165
00:08:41,970 --> 00:08:45,510
the CompTIA IT Fundamentals
if you have no experience.

166
00:08:45,510 --> 00:08:47,850
And, if you want to stick with
Microsoft there's the MTA,

167
00:08:47,850 --> 00:08:51,390
the Microsoft Technology Associate
which again, if you have no experience,

168
00:08:51,390 --> 00:08:53,010
great place to start.

169
00:08:53,010 --> 00:08:57,180
But if you're looking for desktops,
then it's MCSA Windows 8 all the way.

170
00:08:57,180 --> 00:09:01,829
So let's go ahead and get started, and,
if I don't see you before your exam,

171
00:09:01,829 --> 00:09:02,542
good luck.

172
00:09:02,542 --> 00:09:07,611
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Don take a look at advanced installation techniques for Windows 8.1. They discuss supporting Windows To Go as well as creating custom installation images and how to deploy them.
episodes.title: Supporting OS Installation
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,046 --> 00:00:10,046
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:23,586 --> 00:00:33,420
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:33,420 --> 00:00:34,045
All right.

4
00:00:34,045 --> 00:00:35,296
Good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening.

5
00:00:35,296 --> 00:00:35,961
Welcome back.

6
00:00:35,961 --> 00:00:38,766
To another episode of ITPro TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet,

7
00:00:38,766 --> 00:00:40,440
today with Mister Nate Copeland.

8
00:00:40,440 --> 00:00:41,160
How's it going, Nate?

9
00:00:41,160 --> 00:00:41,920
>> Yay.
Pretty good Don.

10
00:00:41,920 --> 00:00:42,670
How are you today?

11
00:00:42,670 --> 00:00:44,628
>> I am doing just swell.

12
00:00:44,628 --> 00:00:46,448
For our proud American viewers,

13
00:00:46,448 --> 00:00:50,878
I think most everybody here in the US is
aware that the Superbowl is this weekend.

14
00:00:50,878 --> 00:00:51,712
>> Mm-hm.

15
00:00:51,712 --> 00:00:52,295
>> Right?

16
00:00:52,295 --> 00:00:53,836
Pumped up for the Superbowl.

17
00:00:53,836 --> 00:00:58,092
My team of choice is of
course the Seattle Sea Hawks,

18
00:00:58,092 --> 00:01:01,510
who are a miserable miserable team.

19
00:01:01,510 --> 00:01:05,530
But I've stuck by them through the years,
but it's so hard after being

20
00:01:05,530 --> 00:01:10,210
beaten down all these years to have
hope that the Superbowl is in our grasp.

21
00:01:10,210 --> 00:01:13,930
But anyhow we're having
a Seattle Sea Hawks day.

22
00:01:13,930 --> 00:01:15,525
And by we I just mean me.

23
00:01:15,525 --> 00:01:16,270
[LAUGH]
>> I know.

24
00:01:16,270 --> 00:01:19,480
If you would've communicated beforehand
then I could have gotten something to go

25
00:01:19,480 --> 00:01:22,160
in my corner in which there is nothing.

26
00:01:22,160 --> 00:01:27,385
But if I did have to choose though I am
going with Seattle for the Superbowl.

27
00:01:27,385 --> 00:01:29,210
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm not, well,

28
00:01:29,210 --> 00:01:30,700
okay, I'm not betting on it.

29
00:01:30,700 --> 00:01:32,480
>> Oh, yeah.
>> I'm not out any money.

30
00:01:32,480 --> 00:01:36,130
But when they score I'll cheer louder for
Seattle.

31
00:01:36,130 --> 00:01:40,420
>> Yeah, well meanwhile our European and
overseas viewers are all saying,

32
00:01:40,420 --> 00:01:43,822
why are they using their hands
when they're playing football?

33
00:01:43,822 --> 00:01:44,334
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

34
00:01:44,334 --> 00:01:45,790
>> So moving on.

35
00:01:45,790 --> 00:01:48,400
We've got a Windows 8 episode up today.

36
00:01:48,400 --> 00:01:53,270
Now, if this is your very
first Windows 8 70-688 exam

37
00:01:53,270 --> 00:01:56,330
episode that you've watched with ITProTV,

38
00:01:56,330 --> 00:01:59,330
then nothing is strange other than
my shirt and the flag behind me.

39
00:01:59,330 --> 00:02:03,900
But if you've been watching all along, you
might have noticed that when you went to

40
00:02:03,900 --> 00:02:08,860
our exam objectives page,
all the links to the videos were gone, and

41
00:02:08,860 --> 00:02:11,410
that they were kind of moved way
down on the bottom of the page.

42
00:02:11,410 --> 00:02:16,700
And what happened is,
as of January 2014, Microsoft finally.

43
00:02:16,700 --> 00:02:20,615
Officially updated the exam

invasive with their software that you

00:27:04,440 --> 00:27:09,600

539
00:27:09,600 --> 00:27:13,810
And we can out one OS in a VHD and

00:27:13,810 --> 00:27:16,420

00:27:21,390 --> 00:27:22,970

00:27:22,970 --> 00:27:27,100

00:27:27,100 --> 00:27:29,970

00:27:29,970 --> 00:27:34,630

546
00:27:34,630 --> 00:27:39,440

547
00:27:39,440 --> 00:27:44,418

00:27:44,418 --> 00:27:49,930

that contains an exact

00:55:28,590 --> 00:55:32,940

00:55:35,910 --> 00:55:37,700
And when you install,

you're just copying that image to

So, what you do,
is you create a reference machine.

1131
00:56:17,670 --> 00:56:22,170
You sit down in your IT Department,
and you take a Windows 8.1 machine.

00:56:22,170 --> 00:56:25,860

00:56:25,860 --> 00:56:30,172

00:56:42,580 --> 00:56:46,930

00:56:46,930 --> 00:56:49,510

00:57:06,371 --> 00:57:09,180

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Nate take a look at application compatibility and coexistence. They discuss and demonstrate the components required for App-V and UE-V and ACT. They also discuss the functionality of RemoteApp and Hyper-V.

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Nate take a look at supporting Windows Store and cloud apps. They demonstrate various methods to install apps such as Office 365 and Windows Intune. They also show how to sideload Windows Store apps as well as integrating a Microsoft account.

551
00:28:32,000 --> 00:28:35,690
Full control, change permissions,
and take ownership.

00:28:35,690 --> 00:28:38,080
And if I turn on full control,

553
00:28:38,080 --> 00:28:42,030
when I go back I'll see that I get that
change permissions and take ownership.

00:28:42,030 --> 00:28:44,760
So let me add that to my notes here.

555
00:28:44,760 --> 00:28:52,572
Full control,
which gives us change permissions.

556
00:28:52,572 --> 00:28:57,360
Change permissions and take ownership.

557
00:28:57,360 --> 00:29:02,270
Now these are some big permissions
right here, these last two.

558
00:29:02,270 --> 00:29:04,860
When you can modify the contents and
delete the contents,

559
00:29:04,860 --> 00:29:08,300
that sounds like you can do pretty much
everything, but change permissions,

560
00:29:08,300 --> 00:29:10,330
we already talked about
a little bit right here.

561
00:29:10,330 --> 00:29:12,960
Which is that's what's actually
going to let us get in there and

00:29:12,960 --> 00:29:15,730
start to change what's going on.

563
00:29:15,730 --> 00:29:19,760
What's going inside of that folder as
far as who's allowed to access it,

564
00:29:19,760 --> 00:29:20,990
who's not allowed to access it.

565
00:29:20,990 --> 00:29:23,820
Same thing with a file,
who can and can't get to it.

566
00:29:23,820 --> 00:29:26,200
If you're ever locked out of a file,
right?

567
00:29:26,200 --> 00:29:31,080
So as an admin if a user locks us out of
a file, we can always exercise the highest

568
00:29:31,080 --> 00:29:33,560
permission, which is this guy right here,
Take ownership.

569
00:29:33,560 --> 00:29:37,390
Even if we're explicitly
denied access on the file.

570
00:29:37,390 --> 00:29:40,740
We can seize ownership, and
take it by force, right?

571
00:29:40,740 --> 00:29:41,750
And that's what this last one is.

572
00:29:41,750 --> 00:29:42,760
So that's a big deal.

573
00:29:42,760 --> 00:29:46,610
If somebody has take ownership permission,
they can not get locked out of the file.

574
00:29:46,610 --> 00:29:49,820
Somebody can try, but
they can always seize ownership back.

575
00:29:49,820 --> 00:29:58,050
So, allows the user to seize
ownership to gain access to a file.

00:29:59,430 --> 00:30:02,050

with the full control.

00:30:02,050 --> 00:30:06,010
So that change permission also allows

the a person to add people to
the access control list, and

00:30:16,870 --> 00:30:17,970

00:30:41,080 --> 00:30:42,770

you're creating an all new file,
a duplicate of that first file.

So, there's now two
copies of the same file.

01:04:39,938 --> 01:04:41,250
Not boobs.

1266
01:04:42,750 --> 01:04:47,450
When you write a file to a hard drive,
you got a couple of pieces to that file.

1267
01:04:47,450 --> 01:04:50,930
You got the file data itself,
that gets written out and

1268
01:04:50,930 --> 01:04:52,748
about somewhere on the drive.

1269
01:04:52,748 --> 01:04:57,370
And then, you've got the actual NTFS table

1270
01:04:57,370 --> 01:05:01,405
data that actually identifies the files

1271
01:05:01,405 --> 01:05:04,275
And, that's normally stored here,
kind of in the inside of the drive.

01:05:04,275 --> 01:05:05,035
Let me do that in red.

1273
01:05:05,035 --> 01:05:06,255
So, it's just kinda marked different.

1274
01:05:06,255 --> 01:05:07,315
All right?

1275
01:05:07,315 --> 01:05:12,165
>> When you copy a file,
if I'm copying to a new hard drive.

1276
01:05:12,165 --> 01:05:15,886
So, if this is my C drive, and
I'm copying to my D drive,

1277
01:05:15,886 --> 01:05:19,777
it's gotta take that data,
it's gotta copy it over here.

1278
01:05:19,777 --> 01:05:23,010
And, it's gotta create an all
new NTFS entry, right?

1279
01:05:23,010 --> 01:05:25,970
So, it's copying it over.

1280
01:05:25,970 --> 01:05:29,600
And so, when that happens, it's all new,
it gets all new permissions.

1281
01:05:29,600 --> 01:05:31,890
Inherits the permissions
to the destination.

1282
01:05:31,890 --> 01:05:35,830
When you copy it within a single drive,

1283
01:05:37,150 --> 01:05:41,690
the data itself has to get duplicated,
you're making a second copy.

1284
01:05:41,690 --> 01:05:44,785
So, a second copy of that data is written,

1285
01:05:44,785 --> 01:05:48,440
and a second entry is made in the NTFS
table identifying that second file.

1286
01:05:48,440 --> 01:05:50,096
So, it's a duplicate,
either way it's a duplicate.

1287
01:05:50,096 --> 01:05:54,730
When you move between drives, so

1288
01:05:54,730 --> 01:05:59,390
if I move a file from the first drive
to the other one, unlike a copy,

1289
01:05:59,390 --> 01:06:02,710
when you move,
the original is removed, it's deleted.

1290
01:06:02,710 --> 01:06:03,710
It's gone.

1291
01:06:03,710 --> 01:06:09,720
So, when I move between two drives,
if I've got my original file over here,

1292
01:06:09,720 --> 01:06:15,200
it copies the data, it creates an entry

1293
01:06:16,210 --> 01:06:20,690
here, and
then it removes the original file.

1294
01:06:20,690 --> 01:06:21,985
Right?
So, the original file goes away.

1295
01:06:21,985 --> 01:06:24,080
That's the point of a move.

1296
01:06:24,080 --> 01:06:28,260
And, because this is an all-new file over

1314

1315

1433
01:13:07,280 --> 01:13:15,270
If you are copying or moving one of these

1434

1436

If it's FAT32, or

When you, when you copy to a network

1439

So yeah, that is another scenario.

1442
01:13:34,330 --> 01:13:36,590
That's a different file system,

01:13:38,040 --> 01:13:40,670

If you've got a thumb drive, and

1446

then you're going to

When we move between drives,

1455

So if I set permissions at the NTFS level,

If I'm in the marketing group and

the sales group,

When we're dealing with multiple groups

You combine all your permissions to

If you're getting denied some kind

And it'll tell you, oh,

or oh it's a condition, or whatever it is,

01:20:49,150 --> 01:20:52,220
it will list what's the cause of why

So perfect if you've got a user,

1697

At the share level, when I share that
sales folder I'm just going to leave

01:26:19,765 --> 01:26:25,403
it at the default, which again,

1704
01:26:28,827 --> 01:26:33,162
And I'm just gonna mark that so
we can remember that it's different,

1705
01:26:33,162 --> 01:26:37,509
that those are the share permissions

01:26:39,170 --> 01:26:42,700

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don talk about IP addressing issues including subnetting and supernetting. They also identify common issues dealing with name resolution and their solutions including Peer Name Resolution Protocol (PNRP) and DNSSEC.
episodes.title: Support Network Connectivity

DNS-

On this machine,

And I know, it's not a static

because I don't have a DHCP server listed.

I'm not pulling an automatic address.

But they can be overridden, and

00:06:57,398 --> 00:06:58,118

00:06:58,118 --> 00:06:59,441
it makes that convenient, doesn't it?

>> Yes.
>> All right.

00:07:01,699 --> 00:07:04,183
So, when I do an ipconfig/all right now,

00:07:04,183 --> 00:07:08,467

00:07:12,298 --> 00:07:17,384
And when I do that, this is where it

00:07:17,384 --> 00:07:23,377

00:07:33,889 --> 00:07:36,084
They'll normally spell it right,

And when you look at it, it shows DHCP

Looking at this, there is no way to

00:08:09,265 --> 00:08:13,340

00:08:13,340 --> 00:08:16,885
This output doesn't tell you exactly

00:08:16,885 --> 00:08:19,265

00:08:19,265 --> 00:08:23,062

00:08:23,062 --> 00:08:26,201
The machine might have been set for

00:08:26,201 --> 00:08:30,898
somebody flipped it to dynamic, just

00:08:30,898 --> 00:08:32,117
>> Right.

209
00:08:32,117 --> 00:08:34,195
>> You might not notice that for
months or years.

210
00:08:34,195 --> 00:08:36,219
>> [LAUGH]
>> It might be when you decommission

00:08:36,219 --> 00:08:38,583
the old DNS servers and
you realize this machine's off.

212
00:08:38,583 --> 00:08:39,976
So there's things like that.

00:08:39,976 --> 00:08:44,714
And the same goes for other things like

214
00:08:44,714 --> 00:08:47,615
those can be overridden
on the interface too.

215
00:08:47,615 --> 00:08:51,114
So the only thing that can't be
overridden when you're set for

216
00:08:51,114 --> 00:08:54,490
DHCP is the IP address,
subnet mask, and default gateway.

217
00:08:54,490 --> 00:08:56,500
Those are the only things
that can't be overwritten.

218
00:08:56,500 --> 00:09:03,530
All right, if we're doing a static
address, though, that's where we've really

00:09:03,530 --> 00:09:07,260
gotta worry about types and problems,
and the typos are easy, you know.

220
00:09:07,260 --> 00:09:10,869
It's just a matter of punching things in.

221
00:09:10,869 --> 00:09:14,857
Maybe my IP address scheme on
this network is 192.168.0, and

222
00:09:14,857 --> 00:09:17,720
I want to be 192.168.0.200, okay?

223
00:09:17,720 --> 00:09:21,800
So I punch that in and there it goes.

224
00:09:21,800 --> 00:09:27,865
But then I go to another network and
it's a 172.16 class B network right.

225
00:09:27,865 --> 00:09:32,390
Well you saw right there a second
ago where it automatically filled

226
00:09:32,390 --> 00:09:36,870
in that subnet for me and if this is
blank when you put in a subnet, when you

227
00:09:36,870 --> 00:09:41,820
put in an address it will automatically
guess what that's going to be.

228
00:09:41,820 --> 00:09:44,513
So if I put in 172.16.0.1,

229
00:09:44,513 --> 00:09:48,180
see how it guessed that it
was supposed to be a class B?

230
00:09:48,180 --> 00:09:49,530
Let me just zoom in on that.

231
00:09:51,120 --> 00:09:52,000
There we go.

232
00:09:52,000 --> 00:09:55,313
So it guessed that it was
supposed to be a class b.

233
00:09:55,313 --> 00:10:01,791
Well then I go home and I need to
get back on my 192.168 network, and

234
00:10:01,791 --> 00:10:07,032
so I go in here and
I punch in 192.168.0.200.

235
00:10:07,032 --> 00:10:09,330
See how didn't guess?

236
00:10:09,330 --> 00:10:13,208
Once there is already a subnet mask in
there it no longer automatically tries to

237
00:10:13,208 --> 00:10:16,323
calculate that field and so
it's very easy to overlook that and

238
00:10:16,323 --> 00:10:18,052
leave the wrong sudden estimate.

239
00:10:18,052 --> 00:10:21,440
>> Yeah, and when you're
statically typing it in, right.

240
00:10:21,440 --> 00:10:25,892
Even then especially subnet mask if
somebody is trying to do this really

00:10:25,892 --> 00:10:29,823
quickly, they may just type in
the wrong number simply by doing

242
00:10:29,823 --> 00:10:33,407
255.255.254 sometimes ends up happening.

243
00:10:33,407 --> 00:10:36,830
Or they just don't fill in the rest of it

244
00:10:36,830 --> 00:10:41,055
>> You know that you know the one that I
always do Ronnie is I'm going to do and

245
00:10:41,055 --> 00:10:45,904
I'm typing right so I'm like 192.167.9 and
then I'm like, oh, wait,

00:10:45,904 --> 00:10:48,007
I didn't want 167 or whatever.

00:10:48,007 --> 00:10:51,860
And you hit your backspace key and
it moves into that previous field,

248
00:10:51,860 --> 00:10:53,928
you start typing for the next thing.

249
00:10:53,928 --> 00:10:55,871
And so it's really easy to screw up and

00:10:55,871 --> 00:11:00,025
you end up with something like 192.160

251
00:11:00,025 --> 00:11:02,445
So definitely easy to make
mistakes like that, so

252
00:11:02,445 --> 00:11:06,565
just verifying the data that's put
in there and just paying attention.

253
00:11:06,565 --> 00:11:09,685
Not just to the last octet, but
to all four octets, you know,

254
00:11:09,685 --> 00:11:11,580
making sure you pay attention to all that.

255
00:11:11,580 --> 00:11:14,880
And you know subnet masks
are pretty important right.

256
00:11:14,880 --> 00:11:20,240
Let's hold off on subnet masks cause they

00:11:20,240 --> 00:11:23,010
In the next segment I want to tackle

00:11:23,010 --> 00:11:26,160
But you got to make sure you got

00:11:26,160 --> 00:11:28,300
If you have the wrong subnet mask,

00:11:28,300 --> 00:11:32,670
your machine may not go to it's default

00:11:32,670 --> 00:11:36,130

262
00:11:36,130 --> 00:11:39,690
So there's where it's sending traffic
to the router that's inappropriate.

263
00:11:39,690 --> 00:11:42,720
So we've got to verify that.

264
00:11:42,720 --> 00:11:45,530
>> And just like we saw earlier

you may end up getting the command prompt

And they're just really saying,

So, they might actually give you

00:12:00,010 --> 00:12:02,740
So, be aware of that, too.

00:12:02,740 --> 00:12:05,830
>> The other thing that we could run

00:12:05,830 --> 00:12:08,020

If we assign an IP address to this machine

00:12:11,840 --> 00:12:15,550
So for example,

00:12:15,550 --> 00:12:16,765

00:12:16,765 --> 00:12:17,305

00:12:17,305 --> 00:12:20,962

>> If you're using DHCP,

00:12:23,454 --> 00:12:27,345

00:12:27,345 --> 00:12:28,910

I'm gonna go back to

00:12:42,950 --> 00:12:44,930

00:12:44,930 --> 00:12:47,221

00:12:47,221 --> 00:12:50,112

00:12:50,112 --> 00:12:55,151

00:12:55,151 --> 00:12:58,480
And so he's going to change his

00:12:58,480 --> 00:13:01,230
And what's going to happen is there's

00:13:01,230 --> 00:13:03,730
Now Windows is pretty smart about it.

00:13:03,730 --> 00:13:09,260
What will happen is if it's a Windows

00:13:09,260 --> 00:13:15,030

293
00:13:15,030 --> 00:13:18,280

00:13:18,280 --> 00:13:21,760
that it doesn't break the first machine,
the machine that was already up.

00:13:21,760 --> 00:13:24,736

00:13:24,736 --> 00:13:26,083

00:13:26,083 --> 00:13:28,463

00:13:28,463 --> 00:13:30,464

00:13:30,464 --> 00:13:31,579

00:13:31,579 --> 00:13:32,360

00:13:32,360 --> 00:13:33,510
221, right.
Where is that?

00:13:33,510 --> 00:13:34,030
Yep, up there.

00:13:34,030 --> 00:13:36,900

00:13:37,950 --> 00:13:41,370
So this machine has it so Ronnie,
when he tried to change his IP,

00:13:41,370 --> 00:13:46,840

00:13:46,840 --> 00:13:50,130
On this machine I don't even

00:13:50,130 --> 00:13:53,410
and that's nice because

00:13:53,410 --> 00:13:57,040
Windows machines behaving and

00:13:57,040 --> 00:14:00,450
But what if it's not a Windows

00:14:00,450 --> 00:14:00,970
Right?

00:14:00,970 --> 00:14:05,980
If I bring up a Cisco router with this

00:14:05,980 --> 00:14:10,640

00:14:10,640 --> 00:14:15,600

00:14:15,600 --> 00:14:18,380
So you'll get little pop-up bubbles

00:14:18,380 --> 00:14:20,400

00:14:20,400 --> 00:14:24,690
Ideally you go in you find the person

00:14:24,690 --> 00:14:28,670
But worst case scenario you can change
your IP to something different to get

318
00:14:28,670 --> 00:14:32,620
around that but you know you do get nice
good diagnostics to pop up to let you know

319
00:14:32,620 --> 00:14:33,800
that that happened.

320
00:14:33,800 --> 00:14:37,030
And in Windows, so did you go back to-
>> I did.

321
00:14:37,030 --> 00:14:38,540
>> What IP do you have now Ronnie?

00:14:38,540 --> 00:14:39,150

00:14:39,150 --> 00:14:39,890
Oops.

00:14:39,890 --> 00:14:42,640

it's coming back up here.

325
00:14:44,120 --> 00:14:48,490
So in Windows it's actually being pretty

326
00:14:48,490 --> 00:14:50,294
When you change your address,

00:14:50,294 --> 00:14:52,435

>> All right.

00:14:52,435 --> 00:14:55,790
So I'm gonna change mine to

00:14:55,790 --> 00:14:59,312
So I'm just gonna punch that in there.

00:14:59,312 --> 00:15:04,792
[NOISE] And
we'll just do it back up like that.

00:15:04,792 --> 00:15:05,790
All right?

00:15:05,790 --> 00:15:08,950
You can actually choose to

00:15:08,950 --> 00:15:13,140
And when you say okay to that,

00:15:13,140 --> 00:15:17,360

00:15:17,360 --> 00:15:20,610
Now when I changed it,

00:15:20,610 --> 00:15:21,610

00:15:21,610 --> 00:15:24,702

00:15:24,702 --> 00:15:28,062
[SOUND] [LAUGH] Did my whole?

00:15:28,062 --> 00:15:29,768
No it did, didn't it?

00:15:29,768 --> 00:15:30,590
Let's see.
We're crazy.

00:15:33,960 --> 00:15:36,510
It's a virtual machine so
I can connect to its console and

00:15:36,510 --> 00:15:38,970
actually see what's on its screen.

343
00:15:38,970 --> 00:15:46,500
And we should see a nice little message

00:15:46,500 --> 00:15:49,146
Let me just get into that real quick and
we'll all see it and

345
00:15:49,146 --> 00:15:52,764
it should be sitting there waiting for us
if not to make the error happen again but

346
00:15:52,764 --> 00:15:56,560
it's cool because it gives you a chance

00:15:56,560 --> 00:15:59,001
And let me undo the change that was made.

348
00:15:59,001 --> 00:16:03,434
And I'm watching Ronnie's laptop over here

349
00:16:03,434 --> 00:16:07,890

00:16:07,890 --> 00:16:12,320
But here we go, on my end,
I've got a message letting me know, hey,

00:16:12,320 --> 00:16:13,610

00:16:13,610 --> 00:16:15,500

00:16:28,770 --> 00:16:31,970

00:16:31,970 --> 00:16:32,850
There we go, all right.

00:16:32,850 --> 00:16:33,680
So 1012326 is what's set.

00:16:33,680 --> 00:16:35,530

00:16:36,950 --> 00:16:40,270
And now, I guess you can't really see it,

Look at that.

00:16:48,890 --> 00:16:49,870
Pay attention.

00:16:49,870 --> 00:16:52,780
So, I can see,

00:16:55,810 --> 00:16:58,870

00:16:58,870 --> 00:17:00,620
And if I take a look at my IP

00:17:00,620 --> 00:17:02,480

00:53:54,936 --> 00:53:59,197
of that, that's the end of the address and
now it works properly.

1063
00:53:59,197 --> 00:54:00,329
So you can kind of override it.

1064
00:54:01,330 --> 00:54:05,120
Well, why is it sticking that
extra domain on the end?

1065
00:54:05,120 --> 00:54:06,750
What the heck is going on there?

1066
00:54:06,750 --> 00:54:11,850
And the thing we have to remember is
that if you do a single name lookup,

1067
00:54:11,850 --> 00:54:15,950
there's three different places
you can get additional DNS values

1068
00:54:15,950 --> 00:54:18,770
attached to that entry, right?

1069
00:54:18,770 --> 00:54:19,980
One is DHCP.

1070
00:54:19,980 --> 00:54:25,680
If you're using DHCP,
when you connect your DACP server,

1071
00:54:25,680 --> 00:54:29,300
it might be handing out a DNS suffix.

1072
00:54:29,300 --> 00:54:32,340
So, right here I've got a DNS
suffix search list, and

1073
00:54:32,340 --> 00:54:34,510
it's currently lab.itpro.tv.

1074
00:54:34,510 --> 00:54:39,720
A second place you can get a DNS
suffix from is your domain.

1075
00:54:39,720 --> 00:54:43,600
If your workstation is joined to a domain,
then you may be pulling one from there.

1076
00:54:43,600 --> 00:54:47,410
And it'll normally show up here as
the primary DNS suffix an so so

1077
00:54:47,410 --> 00:54:52,510
you know, lab.itpro.tv is our internal
domain, and this machine is joined to it.

1078
00:54:52,510 --> 00:54:54,960
So that's two places where we can get it.

1079
00:54:54,960 --> 00:54:58,340
But both of those are really
related to server issues and

1080
00:54:58,340 --> 00:55:00,170
not likely to show up on this exam.

1081
00:55:01,330 --> 00:55:04,150
Another place though that
would show up on this exam

1082
00:55:04,150 --> 00:55:07,450
would be configurations on
the network adapter itself.

1083
00:55:07,450 --> 00:55:08,885
So let me, let me just pull that up.

1084
00:55:12,102 --> 00:55:15,863
So I'm going to go into my IPv4 settings,
here.

1085
00:55:20,759 --> 00:55:22,750
All right, and I've got a static IP.

1086
00:55:22,750 --> 00:55:27,940
I thought I was using DHCP, but I'm not,
So there's one incorrect thing.

1087
00:55:27,940 --> 00:55:28,920
But if I drill down here, and

1088
00:55:28,920 --> 00:55:30,792
I go into my DNS tab
>> There it is

1089
00:55:30,792 --> 00:55:33,307
>> I'll see in here where we can override

1090
00:55:33,307 --> 00:55:38,104
our DNS suffix and you'll see append
primary connection to specific DNS

1091
00:55:38,104 --> 00:55:43,135
suffixes to single name lookups on this
interface and append the suffixes of

1092
00:55:43,135 --> 00:55:48,500
a primary DNS suffix so That's where we're
getting it from DHCP and our domain.

1093
00:55:48,500 --> 00:55:53,441
We can override that if we want by
choosing to appending a suffixes in

1094
00:55:53,441 --> 00:55:58,695
this order, and we can manually
specify ones to use, all right?

1095
00:55:58,695 --> 00:56:04,180
The only issue with doing that is,
if we are dynamically updating DNS, right?

1096
00:56:04,180 --> 00:56:05,355
>> Mm-hm.
>> If we're doing automatic

1097
00:56:05,355 --> 00:56:06,135
name registration.

1098
00:56:06,135 --> 00:56:07,675
>> Right.
>> It's important to go ahead and

1099
00:56:07,675 --> 00:56:10,745
specify a DNS suffix for
this particular connection.

1100
00:56:10,745 --> 00:56:14,815
So, I might say, you know what,
whenever I do a lookup, go ahead and

1101
00:56:14,815 --> 00:56:17,535
look to lab.itpro.tv first.

1102
00:56:18,650 --> 00:56:22,520
And then maybe, if that doesn't work,
go ahead and jump up to itpro.tv and

1103
00:56:22,520 --> 00:56:25,930
do the lookup there, and
see how that works, right?

1104
00:56:25,930 --> 00:56:31,407
But for my connection, when I register, I
want to register with a lab the itpro.tv.

1105
00:56:31,407 --> 00:56:32,670
All right?

1106
00:56:32,670 --> 00:56:33,980
And you'll see right here.

1107
00:56:33,980 --> 00:56:36,780
Use this connection's DNS suffix and
DNS registration,

1108
00:56:36,780 --> 00:56:39,927
that'll make sure that that's
the one that I'm using, all right?

1109
00:56:39,927 --> 00:56:40,590
>> All right.

1110
00:56:40,590 --> 00:56:45,230
>> So I'm overriding the values that
I might be pulling from DACP if I

1111
00:56:45,230 --> 00:56:47,440
were using DACP, which I'm not.

1112
00:56:47,440 --> 00:56:48,590
>> There you go.

1113
00:56:48,590 --> 00:56:50,020
>> All right, so
now when I look at this screen,

1114
00:56:50,020 --> 00:56:51,550
it's not gonna look all
that much different.

1115
00:56:51,550 --> 00:56:54,330
Whoops, it won't look much
different if I can type.

1116
00:56:56,000 --> 00:57:00,700
The main difference will be that here,
where it says DNS subject search list,

1117
00:57:00,700 --> 00:57:04,430
I actually had more than one domain,
it's just not,

1118
00:57:04,430 --> 00:57:08,190
this command doesn't support showing
them all, so I don't see them.

1119
00:57:08,190 --> 00:57:14,980
And if I do an NS lookup for
a particular address, like itprotv-dc2,

1120
00:57:14,980 --> 00:57:20,140
all right,
it's gonna look to lab.itpro.tv first and

1121
00:57:20,140 --> 00:57:24,070
if it doesn't find it there, then it'll
move up and check some of the other ones.

1122
00:57:24,070 --> 00:57:27,835
So if I try like three, you know it's
going to move up and try and find one.

1123
00:57:27,835 --> 00:57:32,504
And see how it looked to
itprotv-dc3.itpro.tv?

1124
00:57:32,504 --> 00:57:37,404
That was the next domain in that list, and
we've got a wildcard DNS value in there,

1125
00:57:37,404 --> 00:57:39,156
which is why this is working.

1126
00:57:39,156 --> 00:57:41,340
We wanted to do it for typos.

1127
00:57:41,340 --> 00:57:48,309
If a viewer goes to our actual site,
it's just itpro.tv, right?

1128
00:57:48,309 --> 00:57:52,210
So, if you wanna go to our website, you
just type in itpro.tv and you get there.

1129
00:57:52,210 --> 00:57:54,850
But what if somebody types in www, right?

1130
00:57:56,260 --> 00:57:59,873
Or if they only type in two w's or
whatever.

1131
00:57:59,873 --> 00:58:04,002
We wanted to make sure they still get to
our site, so we put a wildcard in there,

1132
00:58:04,002 --> 00:58:08,639
and that's why itpro.tv-dc3 is resolving
to our website's address, because that

1133
00:58:08,639 --> 00:58:12,920
was the next thing in my list, it hit that
wildcard, and you get that value back.

1134
00:58:12,920 --> 00:58:13,524
>> Nice.

1135
00:58:13,524 --> 00:58:18,692
>> So just keep in mind with DNS, there
are several layers deep of where you might

1136
00:58:18,692 --> 00:58:24,020
be getting these names from and so on,
and one of the best troubleshooting tools

1137
00:58:24,020 --> 00:58:28,788
that I use is NS lookup with throwing
a period on the end of that DNS name to

1138
00:58:28,788 --> 00:58:33,672
make sure that it doesn't do any kind
of extended suffixes, all right?

1139
00:58:33,672 --> 00:58:37,189
Every once in a while, you'll actually
be able to spot some of these DNS issues

1140
00:58:37,189 --> 00:58:40,067
because you're going to open up a website,
and all of a sudden,

1141
00:58:40,067 --> 00:58:41,852
you type in a name you can't get there.

1142
00:58:41,852 --> 00:58:45,030
Let's say that you're actually doing
this with testing on your own web site.

1143
00:58:45,030 --> 00:58:48,650
If you can get there with an IP
address instead, then you know you

1144
00:58:48,650 --> 00:58:52,430
are having some name resolution issues
that you might have to take care of.

1145
00:58:52,430 --> 00:58:55,609
So helping by using NS lookup, and

1146
00:58:55,609 --> 00:59:00,320
taking a look at those DNS suffixes
can really help us out here.

1147
00:59:00,320 --> 00:59:04,500
Another trick you can use is, if you're
not sure if the problem is your DNS server

1148
00:59:04,500 --> 00:59:08,520
or somebody else's, from the command line,
you can specify in alternate DNS servers.

1149
00:59:08,520 --> 00:59:11,720
So for example,
if I do an NS lookup for CNN.com,

1150
00:59:11,720 --> 00:59:15,310
it's apparently gonna take a minute.

1151
00:59:15,310 --> 00:59:17,360
There we go, and
there's the response that I get.

1152
00:59:17,360 --> 00:59:20,010
You know, it's doing that crazy
thing again, there we go.

1153
00:59:20,010 --> 00:59:22,950
So here's the response that I get,
and I can get some IPs and so on.

1154
00:59:22,950 --> 00:59:24,950
That's from my server right here.

1155
00:59:24,950 --> 00:59:28,100
Well, I can run it against
somebody else's server.

1156
00:59:28,100 --> 00:59:30,690
I could say, you know what,
let's run this against Google's server

1157
00:59:30,690 --> 00:59:34,540
just by adding the IP address of
the server at the end of the list.

1158
00:59:34,540 --> 00:59:37,760
And so when I do that lookup,
here's what Google sees.

1159
00:59:37,760 --> 00:59:40,570
And then I could say, well,
let me try level 3 communications.

1160
00:59:40,570 --> 00:59:42,290
We'll just kind of keep rotating through.

1161
00:59:42,290 --> 00:59:45,410
And we can see the lookup
from more than one server.

1162
00:59:45,410 --> 00:59:48,240
Very useful if you wanna weigh
your internal servers against

1163
00:59:48,240 --> 00:59:49,820
an external server.

1164
00:59:49,820 --> 00:59:54,780
Do be aware, though,
that if you're using ping to do

1165
00:59:54,780 --> 00:59:58,900
DNS lookup testing, I know a lot of people
do that where they'll go ping whatever,

1166
00:59:58,900 --> 01:00:03,020
that ping makes use of the DNS cache.

1167
01:00:03,020 --> 01:00:04,360
NS lookup doesn't.

1168
01:00:04,360 --> 01:00:08,790
NS lookup always initiates a lookup,
but ping will use your cache.

1169
01:00:08,790 --> 01:00:11,650
And so if it resolved
successfully a moment ago, your

1170
01:00:11,650 --> 01:00:15,620
ping may still show that it's successful
even though the DNS server's offline.

1171
01:00:15,620 --> 01:00:21,410
So if you're gonna do that,
you might need to do an IPConfig/flushDNS

1172
01:00:21,410 --> 01:00:24,830
to clear out that DNS cache,
and that'll take care of it.

1173
01:00:24,830 --> 01:00:26,700
You do need to be in elevated, I think.

1174
01:00:26,700 --> 01:00:29,740
Yeah, you do need to run the command
prompt as administrator to do that.

1175
01:00:30,900 --> 01:00:34,010
Personally, because I'm a network admin,
because I work on the networks all

1176
01:00:34,010 --> 01:00:39,320
the time, I get frustrated with my DNS
cache, and so I normally disable it.

1177
01:00:39,320 --> 01:00:42,009
If you ever want to turn
off your DNS cache,

1178
01:00:42,009 --> 01:00:45,560
you know, if you read on the Internet,
people make it out to be this big deal,

1179
01:00:45,560 --> 01:00:47,610
like oh, it saves you so much time.

1180
01:00:47,610 --> 01:00:50,550
Well you know what,
it saves you nanoseconds everyday, and

1181
01:00:50,550 --> 01:00:51,955
I've got nanoseconds to spare.

1182
01:00:51,955 --> 01:00:53,960
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I just turn off the cache so

1183
01:00:53,960 --> 01:00:56,130
my system doesn't look up every time.

1184
01:00:56,130 --> 01:00:59,850
That way I can spot problems faster
than if I had this cache turned on.

1185
01:00:59,850 --> 01:01:00,530
>> Right.

1186
01:01:00,530 --> 01:01:01,929
And it's super easy to turn off.

1187
01:01:01,929 --> 01:01:08,452
You just go into your services, and there
is a service in there called DNS client.

1188
01:01:08,452 --> 01:01:12,401
It's a kind of misleading name.

1189
01:01:12,401 --> 01:01:16,376
See, there it is, DNS Client, because you
read that name thinking all right, well,

1190
01:01:16,376 --> 01:01:20,570
this is the client, this is what does DNS
lookups, I don't want to disable that.

1191
01:01:20,570 --> 01:01:22,770
Well, you can come in here,
and you can stop it.

1192
01:01:22,770 --> 01:01:25,374
I'll just stop it right now, and

1193
01:01:25,374 --> 01:01:30,864
all that does is disable the DNS
client cache, not the client itself.

1194
01:01:30,864 --> 01:01:36,829
I can still do NS lookup for Google.com.

1195
01:01:36,829 --> 01:01:37,389
>> Yep, still working.

1196
01:01:37,389 --> 01:01:38,740
>> Works just fine, right?

1197
01:01:38,740 --> 01:01:42,510
The only difference is,
it's no longer being cached.

1198
01:01:42,510 --> 01:01:45,210
And, Ronnie, do you remember
the command to show the cache?

1199
01:01:45,210 --> 01:01:47,040
There's an ipconfig command that shows it.

1200
01:01:47,040 --> 01:01:48,580
>> Yep, display DNS.

1201
01:01:48,580 --> 01:01:50,840
>> It's what?
>> Display DNS.

1202
01:01:50,840 --> 01:01:51,537
There we go.

1203
01:01:51,537 --> 01:01:55,350
So if I try it right now, I get, could
not display the DNS resolver cache, and

1204
01:01:55,350 --> 01:01:57,720
that's because the cache is disabled.

1205
01:01:57,720 --> 01:02:01,490
And if I come and turn this back on,
I guess it's gonna

1206
01:02:03,050 --> 01:02:06,260
make me need to restart for some reason,
but there we go, I'll turn it back on.

1207
01:02:06,260 --> 01:02:10,931
And now, if I go back here,
and I do a few look-ups, if I.

1208
01:02:16,297 --> 01:02:22,610
I need to use pings instead of DNS lookup,
because DNS lookup doesn't use the cache.

1209
01:02:22,610 --> 01:02:25,920
So I'm just kind of doing a few
things here to get some resolution.

1210
01:02:25,920 --> 01:02:27,485
Apparently you can't ping CNN.

1211
01:02:27,485 --> 01:02:28,736
I'm okay with that though.

1212
01:02:28,736 --> 01:02:31,591
All right, so
if I do a display DNS, there we go,

1213
01:02:31,591 --> 01:02:34,570
I can see those things that
are now in that cache.

1214
01:02:34,570 --> 01:02:38,670
So on your end users' work stations,
you want that cache.

1215
01:02:38,670 --> 01:02:41,870
It just saves them doing repeated
lookups when they're constantly going to

1216
01:02:41,870 --> 01:02:42,950
the same site.

1217
01:02:42,950 --> 01:02:44,800
But as a network admin,
if you're responsible for

1218
01:02:44,800 --> 01:02:47,880
monitoring the network,
not a bad idea to turn that cache off.

1219
01:02:47,880 --> 01:02:50,230
That way you can see problems
as soon as they arise.

1220
01:02:52,420 --> 01:02:55,630
If you take a look at,
you know, my laptop or

1221
01:02:55,630 --> 01:02:59,410
my computer at home and stuff,
I constantly disable that service.

1222
01:02:59,410 --> 01:03:01,720
It's one of my things when
I set up a new machine.

1223
01:03:03,250 --> 01:03:09,090
Anyhow, all right, not necessarily
best practices per se, but useful.

1224
01:03:10,520 --> 01:03:11,180
All right.

1225
01:03:11,180 --> 01:03:12,863
Ronnie, you got anything
else on normal DNS?

1226
01:03:12,863 --> 01:03:14,789
>> Nope.

1227
01:03:14,789 --> 01:03:18,061
Now let's go into the abnormal,
the abnormal DNS.

1228
01:03:18,061 --> 01:03:19,649
>> So let's get into abnormal, right?

1229
01:03:19,649 --> 01:03:21,832
So there's a lot of crazy
stuff that's out there now.

1230
01:03:21,832 --> 01:03:24,774
The DNS stuff I just showed you guys,
that was IPV 4.

1231
01:03:24,774 --> 01:03:26,625
It's the same for IPV 6, right?

1232
01:03:26,625 --> 01:03:31,454
And in fact, I should have shown that,
you know, when you do an NS lookup,

1233
01:03:31,454 --> 01:03:36,640
if there's IPV 6 values,
it'll return IPV 6 addresses also.

1234
01:03:36,640 --> 01:03:38,250
With commands like ping.

1235
01:03:38,250 --> 01:03:42,574
You can actually ping, so
like here I'm doing a ping,

1236
01:03:42,574 --> 01:03:46,910
it's pinging with an IPv4
address by default.

1237
01:03:46,910 --> 01:03:51,615
If you do a -6,
it will force it to try and

1238
01:03:51,615 --> 01:03:55,059
do IPv6, so you can you -6 or -4.

1239
01:03:55,059 --> 01:03:58,755
-4 will force it to use IPv4,
and so it'll try and

1240
01:03:58,755 --> 01:04:01,741
reach out using that protocol,
so it's the same command, but

1241
01:04:01,741 --> 01:04:04,940
you can kinda force it to go one or
the other based on your priorities.

1242
01:04:04,940 --> 01:04:08,120
I've got my laptop set to, or
actually that's not my laptop.

1243
01:04:08,120 --> 01:04:09,520
>> No that's the
>> That machine.

1244
01:04:09,520 --> 01:04:10,690
Oh, it's got a static IP.

1245
01:04:10,690 --> 01:04:12,360
And we didn't assign an IPv6 address.

1246
01:04:12,360 --> 01:04:16,110
>> [LAUGH]
>> So anyhow, if you're trying to use one

1247
01:04:16,110 --> 01:04:21,487
protocol versus the other, you can kind
of force it from the command line.

1248
01:04:21,487 --> 01:04:25,040
But name resolution under IPv6
is kind of a different thing.

1249
01:04:25,040 --> 01:04:27,930
Because in IPv6,

1250
01:04:27,930 --> 01:04:32,340
you don't necessarily have to have DNS
servers just for local resolution.

1251
01:04:32,340 --> 01:04:36,415
We have something called
the Peer Name Resolution Protocol or

1252
01:04:36,415 --> 01:04:41,320
PNRP, that can be used to find
other machines on our network.

1253
01:04:41,320 --> 01:04:44,590
It's kind of like ARP,
the Address Resolution Protocol.

1254
01:04:44,590 --> 01:04:47,140
Where, with ARP you can
send out a broadcast to

1255
01:04:47,140 --> 01:04:48,880
find out somebody's MAC address.

1256
01:04:48,880 --> 01:04:53,770
With PNRP, you use multicasts
to advertise yourself and

1257
01:04:53,770 --> 01:04:57,060
to find other people that
are registered on the network.

1258
01:04:57,060 --> 01:04:59,529
PNRP for the most part, is automatic.

1259
01:04:59,529 --> 01:05:03,066
And, unless you've broken it yourself,
doesn't typically

1260
01:05:03,066 --> 01:05:07,550
require troubleshooting at all,
it just works, it's like an Apple product.

1261
01:05:07,550 --> 01:05:08,652
Right, it's magic.

1262
01:05:08,652 --> 01:05:14,920
So, it works, if your system has an IPv6
address, It's using PNRP out of the box.

1263
01:05:14,920 --> 01:05:16,380
It should be able to
discover other people,

1264
01:05:16,380 --> 01:05:18,200
other people should be
able to discover you.

1265
01:05:18,200 --> 01:05:19,430
And it should work.

1266
01:05:19,430 --> 01:05:21,710
>> Yeah, there's just a couple
of different settings.

1267
01:05:21,710 --> 01:05:22,720
Like on the firewall and

1268
01:05:22,720 --> 01:05:25,440
then a couple of different
settings to actually see it work.

1269
01:05:25,440 --> 01:05:25,970
>> Yeah.

1270
01:05:25,970 --> 01:05:29,290
So I use the operator
should with all of that.

1271
01:05:29,290 --> 01:05:31,220
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH] >> Because in theory it does work.

1272
01:05:31,220 --> 01:05:33,710
But what if you have messed
around with the machine?

1273
01:05:33,710 --> 01:05:35,160
What if you have changed your settings?

1274
01:05:35,160 --> 01:05:36,540
It is possible to break the PNRP.

1275
01:05:36,540 --> 01:05:41,030
The two most common culprits,
one is the firewall,

1276
01:05:41,030 --> 01:05:44,570
like Ronnie mentioned, and
two is the PNRP service.

1277
01:05:44,570 --> 01:05:47,480
If you stop the PNRP service,
it's not going to work.

1278
01:05:47,480 --> 01:05:50,280
I think I'm already in the service
to screen, so let's start there.

1279
01:05:50,280 --> 01:05:54,500
In your services,
if you kind of browse around in there,

1280
01:05:54,500 --> 01:05:59,690
you will find a peer name resolution
protocol, this guy right here.

1281
01:05:59,690 --> 01:06:01,538
Ok, peer name resolution protocol.

1282
01:06:01,538 --> 01:06:05,790
If you wanna do single name lookups of

1283
01:06:05,790 --> 01:06:10,360
hosts on your IPv6 network,
this service has got to be started.

1284
01:06:10,360 --> 01:06:12,370
If it's not started, if it's disabled or

1285
01:06:12,370 --> 01:06:16,250
not running like mine's not running
right now, then, it's not gonna work.

1286
01:06:16,250 --> 01:06:18,650
Now mine's in manual mode.

1287
01:06:18,650 --> 01:06:22,910
When I start to kick off PNRP lookups,
it's gonna start running on it's own.

1288
01:06:22,910 --> 01:06:27,000
But if I want it always to be available,
if I don't have DNS servers on my

1289
01:06:27,000 --> 01:06:30,200
IPv6 network, then I probably
want to set this to automatic so

1290
01:06:30,200 --> 01:06:33,090
that it's always running,
and we can find those peers.

1291
01:06:33,090 --> 01:06:35,580
This would be good in small
work groups environments.

1292
01:06:35,580 --> 01:06:39,900
And, in fact, if you have a Windows Home
group, it will turn that on by default.

1293
01:06:39,900 --> 01:06:43,440
But in a server environment,
we normally have DNS servers, and so

1294
01:06:43,440 --> 01:06:45,380
we don't need this which
is why it's set to manual.

1295
01:06:46,560 --> 01:06:48,367
I'm going to go ahead and
fire mine up though.

1296
01:06:55,652 --> 01:06:56,890
There we go.

1297
01:06:56,890 --> 01:06:58,100
So now I've got PNRP running.

1298
01:07:00,130 --> 01:07:01,690
The other thing is the firewall.

1299
01:07:01,690 --> 01:07:04,720
PNRP, and I made a little note before
this show, let me just bring it up here.

1300
01:07:06,480 --> 01:07:09,940
Oops, that's not it.

1301
01:07:09,940 --> 01:07:11,870
Here we go.

1302
01:07:11,870 --> 01:07:19,178
PNRP, it's a UDP based protocol, so
it uses user datagram, protocol.

1303
01:07:19,178 --> 01:07:23,520
And it works on ports 35, 40, and 1900.

1304
01:07:23,520 --> 01:07:26,180
35, 40 being the main one right.

1305
01:07:26,180 --> 01:07:28,550
That's where PNRP runs but

1306
01:07:28,550 --> 01:07:33,270
it also uses the simple service discovery
protocol, SSDP, which is running at 1900.

1307
01:07:33,270 --> 01:07:36,803
That let's us not only find hosts, but
some of the services that they're running.

1308
01:07:36,803 --> 01:07:40,971
So you know, DNS, or email.

1309
01:07:40,971 --> 01:07:42,510
All sorts of various other services.

1310
01:07:42,510 --> 01:07:44,560
LDAP, mostly, to find domain controllers.

1311
01:07:44,560 --> 01:07:48,570
So it's all sorts of stuff like that,
that is available there.

1312
01:07:48,570 --> 01:07:50,420
These have to be opened
up on the firewall.

1313
01:07:50,420 --> 01:07:54,942
And there's default rules in the Windows
firewall where it should be turned on, but

1314
01:07:54,942 --> 01:07:57,441
it is possible that
they've been turned off.

1315
01:07:57,441 --> 01:07:59,090
I mean,
we can look at this machine to see.

1316
01:08:05,183 --> 01:08:09,722
Or, I want to be advanced security
let me get into that course.

1317
01:08:09,722 --> 01:08:10,453
We're advanced.

1318
01:08:16,342 --> 01:08:19,919
Now, unfortunately Microsoft's
naming convention for

1319
01:08:19,919 --> 01:08:24,960
this stuff is a little quirky, so finding
the entry in here can take just a moment.

1320
01:08:24,960 --> 01:08:28,080
So let me see if I can spot it real quick.

1321
01:08:28,080 --> 01:08:30,284
There's neighbor discovery for ICMP.

1322
01:08:34,191 --> 01:08:36,630
We'll just skim down our list and,
oh there.

1323
01:08:36,630 --> 01:08:39,540
So here,
notice how it says homegroup in PNRP?

1324
01:08:39,540 --> 01:08:44,130
So, I mentioned that if you got
a Windows homegroup set up,

1325
01:08:44,130 --> 01:08:46,950
that it's gonna use PNRP on that
local network and turn it on.

1326
01:08:46,950 --> 01:08:49,810
So, I'm not in a home group,
and so here's the rule,

1327
01:08:49,810 --> 01:08:55,230
but notice how that rule is grey, it's
disabled, so PNRP is not turned on there.

1328
01:08:55,230 --> 01:08:57,363
Now let me just keep skimming,

1329
01:08:57,363 --> 01:09:01,640
cuz I think there is another rule in here,
let me just browse.

1330
01:09:01,640 --> 01:09:04,897
There's SSVP, which is also not turned on.

1331
01:09:04,897 --> 01:09:09,227
And more SSDP, blah blah blah.

1332
01:09:12,184 --> 01:09:13,206
There.

1333
01:09:13,206 --> 01:09:18,000
PNRP, so here we've got it for
Remote Assistance.

1334
01:09:18,000 --> 01:09:20,625
Somebody local on our network
trying to manage us, so again,

1335
01:09:20,625 --> 01:09:25,668
a scoped rule that's only going to allow
certain people to do PNRP to find us.

1336
01:09:25,668 --> 01:09:31,020
And, anybody else?

1337
01:09:31,020 --> 01:09:32,320
Go with Skype, gotta have that one.

1338
01:09:32,320 --> 01:09:35,990
You know, we never even
installed Skype on this machine,

01:09:39,380 --> 01:09:41,550
And that looks like about it, so

1341
01:09:41,550 --> 01:09:46,000
here's PNRP, just for Windows peer
to peer collaboration foundation.

1342
01:09:46,000 --> 01:09:47,420
And that's about it.

1343
01:09:47,420 --> 01:09:51,020
So I found several rules referencing PNRP.

1344
01:09:51,020 --> 01:09:52,630

01:09:52,630 --> 01:09:55,680
If I leave it this way,

1346
01:09:55,680 --> 01:10:00,630
I can use it to find other people,

1347
01:10:00,630 --> 01:10:04,450
So that's one of the big

1348
01:10:04,450 --> 01:10:08,770

we'll need to open up firewall rules.

1349
01:10:08,770 --> 01:10:11,670

1350
01:10:11,670 --> 01:10:17,220

group or Remote Assistance or whatever.

01:10:17,220 --> 01:10:21,080
Or we need to create our own rules, that
open it up for every application to be

1352
01:10:21,080 --> 01:10:24,530
able to use, for doing that main
resolution on the local network.

1353
01:10:25,980 --> 01:10:28,910
Now, a couple of commands for

01:10:28,910 --> 01:10:32,620

1355
01:10:32,620 --> 01:10:34,630
A couple of commands that we can use.

1356
01:10:34,630 --> 01:10:39,060
The way PNRP works,
is it defines what are called clouds.

1357
01:10:39,060 --> 01:10:43,482
Each of your IPv6 network interfaces
are identified as having a cloud.

1358
01:10:43,482 --> 01:10:47,772
It maps names to IPv6 addresses and
ties them to a cloud cache, so

1359
01:10:47,772 --> 01:10:50,347
it's got a cache for each of the cloud.

1360
01:10:50,347 --> 01:10:53,354
And you know a cloud, it's just a network,
so each network that it sees,

1361
01:10:53,354 --> 01:10:54,730
it identifies it.

1362
01:10:54,730 --> 01:10:57,740
So the three commands that I use for
troubleshooting.

1363
01:10:57,740 --> 01:11:02,050
First off,
you can pull up a list of your clouds.

1364
01:11:02,050 --> 01:11:03,750
So just give me a list of
the clouds that I've got.

1365
01:11:05,120 --> 01:11:09,810
You can pull up a detailed list of your
clouds using another netsh command.

1366
01:11:09,810 --> 01:11:11,829
So netsh is kind of our go to guy for
this.

1367
01:11:13,280 --> 01:11:18,200
Once we see our clouds,
then we can test PNRP, and

1368
01:11:18,200 --> 01:11:23,970
you test it by doing, basically a ping,
using PNRP for the lookup.

1369
01:11:23,970 --> 01:11:28,364
Because ping by default will use DNS and
so it's not a good way to test PNRP.

1370
01:11:28,364 --> 01:11:31,458
we need to use a netsh command to do it.

1371
01:11:31,458 --> 01:11:35,189
If we want to see that in action,
I can try and find Ronnie's machine,

1372
01:11:35,189 --> 01:11:38,000

01:12:05,750 --> 01:12:09,440

01:12:12,710 --> 01:12:15,380

1389
01:12:28,350 --> 01:12:36,592
Netsh p2p because it's peer to peer,

That's gonna give me a summary of

trouble shooting thing that we might

1485
01:16:57,590 --> 01:17:00,880
Now, if you're not familiar with DNSsec or
D-N-S-S-E-C.

1486
01:17:00,880 --> 01:17:05,350
It's a new security protocol that's
being implemented on the root DNS

1487
01:17:05,350 --> 01:17:07,130
servers on the internet.

1488
01:17:07,130 --> 01:17:10,190
And it's the reaction to a number of

1489
01:17:10,190 --> 01:17:13,590
high visibility DNS attacks that
have happened in the last few years.

1490
01:17:13,590 --> 01:17:19,640
It's primarily a server to server method
for authenticating DNS servers and

1491
01:17:19,640 --> 01:17:24,280
ensuring that we're not getting malicious
or poisoned DNS results, right.

1492
01:17:24,280 --> 01:17:29,410
The DNS cache on a DNS server is a high,
it's a big target, right?

1493
01:17:29,410 --> 01:17:32,130
So DNSSec is designed to fix that.

1494
01:17:32,130 --> 01:17:35,800
Well, if it's a server technology and
it's protecting servers,

1495
01:17:35,800 --> 01:17:39,770
you might ask yourself, why do we need
to talk about it in Windows 8 show?

There's not really a whole lot we do here.

But Windows 8 is one of
the few operating systems,

1499
01:17:47,170 --> 01:17:50,230
that's an operating system
that is DNSSec aware.
