1506
01:18:02,046 --> 01:18:06,491
>> And that is what Microsoft is
calling out in this objective,

1507
01:18:06,491 --> 01:18:09,463
which is where they just say and DNS set.

1508
01:18:09,463 --> 01:18:10,055
>> Yeah.

1509
01:18:10,055 --> 01:18:13,473
>> What they're saying is not necessarily
troubleshooting DNS sec on a Windows 8

1510
01:18:13,473 --> 01:18:15,238
machine, cuz it can't do validation.

1511
01:18:15,238 --> 01:18:18,160
But just using it to troubleshoot
problems on our servers.

1512
01:18:18,160 --> 01:18:21,610
>> Yeah, some of the things that ended up
happening right with that DNS cache is

1513
01:18:21,610 --> 01:18:23,560
you may actually go to a DNS server.

1514
01:18:23,560 --> 01:18:26,110
How do you know that you're actually
getting the right response back?

1515
01:18:26,110 --> 01:18:30,450
So one of the things we can do is actually
build or use some of the DNS utilities

1516
01:18:30,450 --> 01:18:34,870
that prove that we're actually getting the
actual right record from the right server.

1517
01:18:34,870 --> 01:18:35,548
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah.

1518
01:18:35,548 --> 01:18:38,790
>> So with DNSSec basically what
happens is the servers start to

1519
01:18:38,790 --> 01:18:41,160
digitally sign their zones.

1520
01:18:41,160 --> 01:18:44,410
And if there's ever an update that comes
through it has to have a digital signature

1521
01:18:44,410 --> 01:18:45,000
that matches.

1522
01:18:45,000 --> 01:18:46,727
>> Right.
>> And you can quickly validate

1523
01:18:46,727 --> 01:18:49,563
the results you're getting
are from a trusted server.

1524
01:18:49,563 --> 01:18:53,710
A server that has a certificate
that you validated, and you accept.

1525
01:18:53,710 --> 01:18:58,320
So the problem is when you configure on
a server how do you verify that it works?

1526
01:18:58,320 --> 01:19:02,500
And that's where you need a client
that's DNSSec aware to test with it.

1527
01:19:02,500 --> 01:19:05,820
In Windows 8 we got a snazzy little
PowerShell command that we can use just

1528
01:19:05,820 --> 01:19:06,640
for that purpose.

1529
01:19:06,640 --> 01:19:11,740
So let me pull up my Windows 8 machine,
which I got a ton of windows open on.

1530
01:19:11,740 --> 01:19:15,588
And what we can do is in
the PowerShell we have

1531
01:19:15,588 --> 01:19:19,644
a command which let's
us do name resolution.

1532
01:19:19,644 --> 01:19:23,446
So we can do resolves
not resolved dash name,

1533
01:19:23,446 --> 01:19:26,860
it is really poor resolve dash DNS name.

1534
01:19:26,860 --> 01:19:28,617
There we go.

1535
01:19:28,617 --> 01:19:29,520
There.

1536
01:19:29,520 --> 01:19:30,950
Resolve-dnsname.

1537
01:19:30,950 --> 01:19:33,416
It's a PowerShell command
that's a part of Windows 8.

1538
01:19:33,416 --> 01:19:35,708
And it let's us do name lookup, all right?

1539
01:19:35,708 --> 01:19:38,090
Well, as far as doing
just a basic name lookup,

1540
01:19:38,090 --> 01:19:42,090
the way the command works is you specify
a name and you specify a server.

1541
01:19:42,090 --> 01:19:44,833
And then it just does
a regular DNS lookup.

1542
01:19:44,833 --> 01:19:49,000
But there's a cool modifier for the
command, let me just bring that up here.

1543
01:19:49,000 --> 01:19:51,770
And, you know,
my notes are getting a little messy, so

1544
01:19:51,770 --> 01:19:53,870
let me just kind of get it so
it's the only thing on the screen.

1545
01:19:53,870 --> 01:19:54,960
There we go.

1546
01:19:54,960 --> 01:20:00,570
So what you can see is resolve-dnsname,
and we specify a name and a server.

1547
01:20:00,570 --> 01:20:04,470
Now, If we just do it that way,
it's the same thing as NSlookup.

1548
01:20:04,470 --> 01:20:09,060
It's looking up the host name on a DNS
server and providing you a result.

1549
01:20:09,060 --> 01:20:14,940
But if you add this extra flag,
DnssecOk, right?

1550
01:20:14,940 --> 01:20:19,160
That says, verify that DNS security
is turned on and okay, and

1551
01:20:19,160 --> 01:20:20,960
give us a little bit of
information about it.

1552
01:20:20,960 --> 01:20:25,482
It's a great way to test and see whether
your servers are properly handling DNSSEC.

1553
01:20:25,482 --> 01:20:29,440
All right, so
I just set up a little example.

1554
01:20:29,440 --> 01:20:31,060
I created two zones.

1555
01:20:31,060 --> 01:20:37,450
I created a zone called signedzone.com and
another one called unsignedzone.com.

1556
01:20:37,450 --> 01:20:41,980
And I digitally signed the signedzone.com
and I didn't do it on the other one.

1557
01:20:41,980 --> 01:20:46,770
So we can use resolve-dnsname to verify
whether or not those are signed or not.

1558
01:20:46,770 --> 01:20:47,690
>> Yeah.
>> Okay.

1559
01:20:47,690 --> 01:20:52,142
So let me just go back to my server here,
and let me just break out of that.

1560
01:20:52,142 --> 01:20:57,140
All right, and so
I'm going to say resolve-dnsname, and for

1561
01:20:57,140 --> 01:21:04,150
the name I'm just going to
say host.unsignedzone.com.

1562
01:21:04,150 --> 01:21:05,260
Did I spell it right?

1563
01:21:05,260 --> 01:21:05,940
Yes.

1564
01:21:05,940 --> 01:21:08,930
And then for the server,
I'll specify my server.

1565
01:21:08,930 --> 01:21:13,430
Now, if I just leave it like this,
it's just doing a normal DNS lookup.

1566
01:21:13,430 --> 01:21:15,710
It'll give me the same
information that NS lookup would.

1567
01:21:15,710 --> 01:21:19,940
Here's the IP address of that host.

1568
01:21:19,940 --> 01:21:20,920
Okay?

1569
01:21:20,920 --> 01:21:27,790
But if I add the DnssecOK flag, all right?

1570
01:21:27,790 --> 01:21:30,510
It's also going to validate DNSsec.

1571
01:21:30,510 --> 01:21:33,870
Now when I run it here,
I get my query back and

1572
01:21:33,870 --> 01:21:37,600
I get my result, but
there is no certificate information.

1573
01:21:37,600 --> 01:21:40,540
And that's because this
is an unsigned zone.

1574
01:21:40,540 --> 01:21:42,450
DNSsec is not enabled on this one.

1575
01:21:44,070 --> 01:21:49,290
But if I switch, and lookup against
my signed zone that I created.

1576
01:21:49,290 --> 01:21:51,810
This is the one that I digitally signed.

1577
01:21:51,810 --> 01:21:56,365
When I run it,
in addition to the lookup, I get that

1578
01:21:56,365 --> 01:22:01,620
it was able to pull an RSA signature.

1579
01:22:01,620 --> 01:22:03,870
So it was able to pull
that digital signature.

1580
01:22:03,870 --> 01:22:05,770
I got an answer back from that server.

1581
01:22:05,770 --> 01:22:08,680
It was signed by signedzone.com.

1582
01:22:08,680 --> 01:22:11,570
The certificate expires March 3rd, 2014.

1583
01:22:11,570 --> 01:22:15,050
So I can see that it is
a valid certificate.

1584
01:22:15,050 --> 01:22:16,430
From a host that I trust.

1585
01:22:16,430 --> 01:22:17,430
And I allowed it.

1586
01:22:17,430 --> 01:22:19,180
And it's a good connection.

1587
01:22:19,180 --> 01:22:19,750
All right?

1588
01:22:19,750 --> 01:22:20,500
So, quick and

1589
01:22:20,500 --> 01:22:24,550
easy way that we can validate that DNSsec
is working on our server, versus not.

1590
01:22:24,550 --> 01:22:26,600
When it's working, we see the certificate.

1591
01:22:26,600 --> 01:22:29,810
When it's not working,
we don't see the certificate.

1592
01:22:29,810 --> 01:22:30,600
Right?

1593
01:22:30,600 --> 01:22:35,880
And if you're just doing the DNS lookups
themselves, right, just for the unsigned

1594
01:22:35,880 --> 01:22:41,180
and for the signed, you don't notice, you
don't see whether DNSsec is being used.

1595
01:22:41,180 --> 01:22:46,700
All right, so keep in mind that
with DNSsec, basically you're

1596
01:22:46,700 --> 01:22:50,990
validating whether or not the result
you're getting back is from a true server.

1597
01:22:50,990 --> 01:22:53,400
And those servers can do that,
they can validate.

1598
01:22:53,400 --> 01:22:56,020
So, when DNS records are being handed off

1599
01:22:56,020 --> 01:22:59,660
recursively from server to server to
server to server, they can validate.

1600
01:22:59,660 --> 01:23:01,260
They can ensure they haven't
been tampered with and

1601
01:23:01,260 --> 01:23:03,460
they're not from malicious sources.

1602
01:23:03,460 --> 01:23:05,920
From a client, we can't do that.

1603
01:23:05,920 --> 01:23:10,750
We can just see that it's happening by
querying the server using resolve-dnsname.

1604
01:23:10,750 --> 01:23:14,980
And it's a great idea to remember that
command right there for the exam,

1605
01:23:14,980 --> 01:23:19,530
especially with the extra
little add on of DnssecOK.

1606
01:23:19,530 --> 01:23:21,970
It's not the easiest one to remember.

1607
01:23:23,880 --> 01:23:26,950
But that's basically DNS security.

1608
01:23:26,950 --> 01:23:31,160
It's a great technology,
it's rolled out already on the Internet so

1609
01:23:31,160 --> 01:23:36,170
you can actually run this kind of test
against servers out there on the Internet.

1610
01:23:36,170 --> 01:23:37,900
Let me try, we'll experiment.

1611
01:23:37,900 --> 01:23:44,161
Let's do a lookup for www.google.com.

1612
01:23:44,161 --> 01:23:49,780
And I'll do it against
one of Google's servers.

1613
01:23:49,780 --> 01:23:51,020
Now this isn't a root server.

1614
01:23:51,020 --> 01:23:55,020
The root servers are where DNSsec was
rolled out in the very beginning.

1615
01:23:55,020 --> 01:23:59,930
When I run a query against them,
nope, they are not running DNSsec.

1616
01:23:59,930 --> 01:24:02,690
Let's try Level3,
we'll see if we can find somebody.

1617
01:24:05,960 --> 01:24:06,650
Nope.

1618
01:24:06,650 --> 01:24:08,410
Let's pull an actual root server.

1619
01:24:08,410 --> 01:24:09,410
Let's go crazy.

1620
01:24:09,410 --> 01:24:11,402
They might not be
allowing me to do DNSsec.

1621
01:24:11,402 --> 01:24:15,920
You know, when you do DNS lookups,

1622
01:24:15,920 --> 01:24:19,350
they expect you to do it against
the down-level server, not a root.

1623
01:24:19,350 --> 01:24:23,490
So, I'm gonna give it a shot here, and
try against one of the root servers.

1624
01:24:23,490 --> 01:24:25,290
I'll just take the first
one that I find here.

1625
01:24:27,810 --> 01:24:29,525
I'm kinda curious to see what'll happen.

1626
01:24:29,525 --> 01:24:33,960
[LAUGH] It's probably gonna
be very anticlimactic.

1627
01:24:33,960 --> 01:24:36,770
You know we feel like something
really cool is gonna happen.

1628
01:24:39,360 --> 01:24:43,850
And resource unavailable,
RCODE server failure.

1629
01:24:43,850 --> 01:24:44,440
That's different.

1630
01:24:47,980 --> 01:24:49,910
I'm gonna get rid of my trailing dot.

1631
01:24:49,910 --> 01:24:54,999
Resource unavailable.

1632
01:24:57,310 --> 01:24:59,450
That server must not be
allowing direct connections.

1633
01:25:01,850 --> 01:25:05,260
Let me try one of the Icam ones,
we'll try a different IP.

1634
01:25:05,260 --> 01:25:08,280
If it doesn't work, they might not
be allowing client connections.

1635
01:25:08,280 --> 01:25:12,120
The root servers are very busy handling
referrals from other DNS servers.

1636
01:25:12,120 --> 01:25:16,360
So they are more than likely just
blocking the connection from a client.

1637
01:25:16,360 --> 01:25:19,790
Why let a client do a run
against an actual root server?

1638
01:25:20,790 --> 01:25:22,049
That would be crazy talk.

1639
01:25:25,543 --> 01:25:27,088
Yeah, that must be what's going on.

1640
01:25:27,088 --> 01:25:28,757
So on my own internal servers, though,

1641
01:25:28,757 --> 01:25:30,880
I am allowing connections
directly from a client.

1642
01:25:30,880 --> 01:25:34,150
And so I can see it,
just against our server, just fine.

1643
01:25:34,150 --> 01:25:37,220
And that's just a great way to verify,
making sure that works.

1644
01:25:37,220 --> 01:25:39,580
You've got to verify from somewhere and
this'll do it.

1645
01:25:39,580 --> 01:25:44,435
It applies on the server also, so
it's really just that same process.

1646
01:25:44,435 --> 01:25:49,924
Yeah, let me just do one
more with a signed host.

1647
01:25:54,185 --> 01:25:54,730
There we go.

1648
01:25:54,730 --> 01:25:56,640
Again, just validating that
we got that certificate.

1649
01:25:56,640 --> 01:25:58,180
All right.
So, that's all we really need to

1650
01:25:58,180 --> 01:25:59,230
know about DNSsec.

1651
01:25:59,230 --> 01:26:01,720
So, if we run through
those commands again.

1652
01:26:01,720 --> 01:26:04,530
We had PNRP, right, where we needed
to verify that our firewall had ports

1653
01:26:04,530 --> 01:26:07,610
open and that we were able to
detect other people on the network.

1654
01:26:07,610 --> 01:26:10,730
But DNSsec, we just need to be able to
validate that a certificate is showing up

1655
01:26:10,730 --> 01:26:12,350
for that zone and that we trust it, right?

1656
01:26:12,350 --> 01:26:14,340
That we're allowing
the results to come through.

1657
01:26:14,340 --> 01:26:17,480
And the other bullet point in
the objective was just straight up,

1658
01:26:17,480 --> 01:26:19,160
regular name resolution.

1659
01:26:19,160 --> 01:26:22,620
There we need to worry about what
nameservers we specified in our config,

1660
01:26:22,620 --> 01:26:24,200
as well as our DNS suffixes.

1661
01:26:24,200 --> 01:26:28,270
And that they can come from multiple
places like the domain that we've joined,

1662
01:26:28,270 --> 01:26:30,880
the suffix we attached
directly to the interface, or

1663
01:26:30,880 --> 01:26:34,320
suffixes that we learned
from a DHCP server.

1664
01:26:34,320 --> 01:26:37,350
>> Remember in the IP configurations
that we actually had,

1665
01:26:37,350 --> 01:26:40,620
a lot of problems really do stem
from static configurations.

1666
01:26:40,620 --> 01:26:43,490
Where we tend to have more, again,

1667
01:26:43,490 --> 01:26:47,795
typos than anything else, as well
as just missing information, right?

1668
01:26:47,795 --> 01:26:52,710
Taking a look at this subnet mask,
verifying the idea of the default gateway

1669
01:26:52,710 --> 01:26:56,340
and the actual IP address of that
host are on the same network, too.

1670
01:26:58,440 --> 01:27:01,190
>> All right, well, Ronnie,
that's probably a pretty good spot for

1671
01:27:01,190 --> 01:27:02,350
us to wrap up the show.

1672
01:27:02,350 --> 01:27:03,330
>> Sounds great.
>> Like I said,

1673
01:27:03,330 --> 01:27:05,370
we do have two more bullet
points in this objective.

1674
01:27:05,370 --> 01:27:06,790
We've got wireless networks and

1675
01:27:06,790 --> 01:27:09,520
connections that we need to work
on troubleshooting and managing.

1676
01:27:09,520 --> 01:27:13,367
And then lastly, we've got network
security including Windows Firewall and

1677
01:27:13,367 --> 01:27:15,240
IPsec, right, IP security.

1678
01:27:15,240 --> 01:27:18,685
There's a pretty big topic right there, so
what we're gonna do is we're going to go

1679
01:27:18,685 --> 01:27:20,990
ahead and wrap it up right here for

Stay tuned, though, because it'll

A link at the top.

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Ronnie discuss network security using Windows Firewall and IP security. They describe methods to restrict applications using inbound and outbound rules with Windows Firewall with Advanced Security as well as securing traffic between two endpoints using IPSec in the Connection Security Rules.

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Ronnie discuss the qualities and potential pitfalls of implementing Encrypting File System (EFS) to secure files and folders on a NTFS drive and demonstrate its use. They show encrypting a file and how it restricts access to other users and the use of cipher.exe to create a data recovery agent.

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Ronnie take the opportunity to show two networking technologies that Windows 8.1 users may need to use: HomeGroup and Workplace Join.  They talk about scenarios in which you may choose to use either technologies and show the basic configuration of both as well as discuss some issues you may encounter in troubleshooting.

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Ronnie discuss the usage and management of removable storage devices on Windows 8.1.  They show all of the device managements features found in the local policy as well as demonstrate how to use them in conjunction with each other to make an effective policy for managing remote devices.

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Ronnie identify data storage options that Windows 8.1 supports natively and talk about issues creating them and connecting with them.  They specifically show the creation and management of storage spaces.  They identify the common uses of Branchcache and configure the client to connect to a Branchcache server.  They talk about the benefits of using DFS and identify some of the command line utilities to verify its operation. Lastly, they mention the differences between SkyDrive(OneDrive) and SkyDrive Pro
episodes.title: Supporting Data Storage

00:22:44,450 --> 00:22:47,230

For us in terms of branch cache, okay.

551
00:22:47,230 --> 00:22:50,860
This is really designed for
businesses that have multiple sites, or

552
00:22:50,860 --> 00:22:55,660
multiple locations that they need to, to
be able to connect to and to share files.

553
00:22:55,660 --> 00:22:57,480
So it's not uncommon that, you know,

554
00:22:57,480 --> 00:23:00,280
you have a main office a lot of times and
you have a branch office.

555
00:23:00,280 --> 00:23:03,060
And let's say that daily what
ends up happening is that

556
00:23:03,060 --> 00:23:08,500
people at the branch office are constantly
going across the actual connection here

557
00:23:08,500 --> 00:23:11,910
to retrieve copies of files and
download them.

558
00:23:11,910 --> 00:23:15,120
And it's not that it's a bad thing,
but let's say that you have ten or

559
00:23:15,120 --> 00:23:17,650
15 users at that branch office and

560
00:23:17,650 --> 00:23:22,600
they're really retrieving let's say
the same copy of files all the time.

561
00:23:22,600 --> 00:23:25,910
So there's a lot of the same files
that are going across that link.

562
00:23:25,910 --> 00:23:28,170
Now sometimes though
those links can be well,

563
00:23:28,170 --> 00:23:32,570
relatively anemic in terms of how much
data we can push through them at one time.

564
00:23:32,570 --> 00:23:37,050
They can become slow if you actually have
data transfers going on in the background.

565
00:23:37,050 --> 00:23:42,210
So what the idea of branch cache does for
us here, okay, is gives us the ability

566
00:23:42,210 --> 00:23:47,020
to essentially download the files
one time across that link.

567
00:23:47,020 --> 00:23:50,644
And then instead of actually having
every other user at that site,

568
00:23:50,644 --> 00:23:53,630
try to connect all the way
back over to the main office.

569
00:23:53,630 --> 00:23:56,818
When they do it's gonna
redirect them pass you,

570
00:23:56,818 --> 00:24:00,880
point to a local storage on their
side of the network instead.

571
00:24:00,880 --> 00:24:04,946
So it really does help, especially over
slow connections is where it really

572
00:24:04,946 --> 00:24:07,330
does actually do its main job here.

573
00:24:07,330 --> 00:24:07,940
Yeah.

574
00:24:07,940 --> 00:24:08,560
Okay?

575
00:24:08,560 --> 00:24:09,140
>> Mm-hm.

576
00:24:09,140 --> 00:24:09,680

00:24:09,680 --> 00:24:10,470
Now, so yeah.

578
00:24:10,470 --> 00:24:15,570
So, you know, to, to check whether the
file has changed or not, it uses hashing.

579
00:24:15,570 --> 00:24:17,490
>> Mm-hm.
>> So it'll take a hash of that file and

580
00:24:17,490 --> 00:24:22,750
as the client reaches out to look for
that file then the, the,

581
00:24:22,750 --> 00:24:26,410
cache server will check with the content
server and if the hashes are the same,

582
00:24:26,410 --> 00:24:30,814
the file remains unchanged and then it is,
yeah, sent down to the client.

583
00:24:30,814 --> 00:24:33,200
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> Yep, yep, from that cache.

584
00:24:33,200 --> 00:24:36,960
And, of course, if it's changed then, you
know, as the client pulls down that new

585
00:24:36,960 --> 00:24:41,530
copy the, the caching server
then will keep a copy of it and

586
00:24:41,530 --> 00:24:45,270
anybody else that needs to get it can then
get it from that cached copy as well.

587
00:24:45,270 --> 00:24:46,130
>> Yeah, so

588
00:24:46,130 --> 00:24:50,970
there's a lot of things going on in the
background in terms of branch cache here.

589
00:24:50,970 --> 00:24:51,700
'Kay?

00:24:51,700 --> 00:24:55,300
Now for us,
there's really two basic systems of this

00:24:55,300 --> 00:24:57,910
that we have to understand

592
00:24:57,910 --> 00:25:04,220
If your bigger office, that's the branch
office has a server ready to go.

593
00:25:04,220 --> 00:25:05,000
'Kay?

594
00:25:05,000 --> 00:25:09,440
What we can do is we can redirect all of
the actual caching happening into this

595
00:25:09,440 --> 00:25:10,050
one server.

596
00:25:10,050 --> 00:25:13,480
And that is what we call BranchCache
posted mode is what it is.

597
00:25:13,480 --> 00:25:16,950
And what that means is when they actually
get redirected they'll all actually pull

598
00:25:16,950 --> 00:25:20,140
off this one file server,
which is a really good thing.

599
00:25:20,140 --> 00:25:20,750
Okay?

600
00:25:20,750 --> 00:25:25,620
But what if your site is a relatively new
site and you don't actually have any other

601
00:25:25,620 --> 00:25:29,920

602
00:25:29,920 --> 00:25:33,310
Well, you can actually run what's
called distributed mode here.

603
00:25:33,310 --> 00:25:36,770
In which if you're the first one to
connect, the information will be cached on

604
00:25:36,770 --> 00:25:41,550
your machine and then when a second
user tries to go on connect over and

605
00:25:41,550 --> 00:25:45,290
if again the file hasn't changed, then
I'll actually connect to your machine and

606
00:25:45,290 --> 00:25:46,690
download it from there.

607
00:25:46,690 --> 00:25:50,240
So, it actually makes it a lot easier
to actually be able to do this.

608
00:25:50,240 --> 00:25:50,970
'Kay.

00:25:50,970 --> 00:25:54,170
And then, actually work faster
because your internal networks

00:25:54,170 --> 00:25:58,240

connection back over to the the,

611
00:25:58,240 --> 00:25:59,305
the connection to the main office.

00:25:59,305 --> 00:26:00,450
>> Mm-hm.

and when using the distributed cache mode

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Ronnie focus on Bitlocker support for Windows 8.1 users.  They briefly review Bitlocker and Bitlocker-To-Go technology.  They describe scenarios for recovering bitlocker encrpyted drives including manually using the password stored as a file, the use of a data recovery agent and group policy and Microsoft Bitlocker Administrating and Monitoring.

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Ronnie talk about some of the different authentication methods that are supported in Windows 8.1.  The methods include, virtual smart cards, certificates, picture passwords and use of biometric authentication which are native supported in Windows 8.1.  They discuss common issues using local accounts, domain accounts and Microsoft accounts.
episodes.title: Authentication and Authorization

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Don discuss the process of supporting various solutions of remote access. They demonstrate how to leverage the Connection Manager Administration Kit (CMAK) to rollout VPN access to users. They also cover Remote Desktop Services Gateway access as well as verifying the status of Network Access Protection from the client side.
episodes.title: Support Remote Access

00:36:52,120 --> 00:36:52,990

And let's say that Nate was VPNed in,

So what I like to do is just kind

So I usually start by pinging myself and

00:37:13,840 --> 00:37:15,790
let's go ahead and do this,
127, I mean you know it.

00:37:15,790 --> 00:37:19,810
I'm telling you something
you already know, 127.0.0.1.

00:37:19,810 --> 00:37:22,000
Pinging the loopback is just a chance for

00:37:22,000 --> 00:37:24,565
us to test the TCP/IP protocol stack,
right?

801
00:37:24,565 --> 00:37:27,800
Just software, verifying that
software works and that it's okay.

802
00:37:27,800 --> 00:37:30,790
So this one's good, where fine, right?

803
00:37:30,790 --> 00:37:35,580
Then we can test our hardware by
pinging our own IP address, all right?

00:37:35,580 --> 00:37:37,880
Now, I don't know what our IP address is,
what is our IP?

00:37:40,090 --> 00:37:43,171
10.1.230.77.

00:37:43,171 --> 00:37:48,819
So let's go ahead and ping 10.1.230.77
that's our network adapter for

807
00:37:48,819 --> 00:37:50,578
our individual machine.

808
00:37:55,885 --> 00:37:59,260
This is actually gonna touch hardware
when you ping your loopback,

809
00:37:59,260 --> 00:38:00,990
it's just doing software.

810
00:38:00,990 --> 00:38:03,650
This is gonna to touch hardware and
make sure that we're actually able to

00:38:05,810 --> 00:38:08,620

00:38:08,620 --> 00:38:10,880
If this passes, then you're good, right?

00:38:31,185 --> 00:38:34,845

this is the internal IP of the VPN server,

00:39:20,910 --> 00:39:23,380

00:40:06,320 --> 00:40:09,805

00:40:09,805 --> 00:40:11,477

00:40:11,477 --> 00:40:15,219

If they both fail, then you know that

00:40:20,033 --> 00:40:21,580

00:40:21,580 --> 00:40:22,238

And you can correct that

00:40:31,180 --> 00:40:34,813
That's to say,

So as to build those connections.

00:40:36,329 --> 00:40:36,841
All right.

So simple process testing inside out.

the point
>> Well,

1023
00:47:30,590 --> 00:47:31,715
Inbound to a machine.

1024
00:47:31,715 --> 00:47:34,300
So, it would be in
the inbound rules up there.

00:47:35,770 --> 00:47:38,725
And it should be pretty
alphabetical order,

1026
00:47:38,725 --> 00:47:41,375
so I'll just check for remote desktop.

1027
00:47:44,562 --> 00:47:45,171
All right.
So there we go.

So we have, [COUGH] a few in here.

00:47:48,442 --> 00:47:56,250
Now depending on our network location, so
whether it's on domain, public or private.

We have different ones here, so
there's two of these shadow TCP-IN.

00:48:00,513 --> 00:48:01,560

00:48:01,560 --> 00:48:06,374
So one is for public, the other one
is set for the domain profile and so

1033
00:48:06,374 --> 00:48:08,460
we have those set for domain.

1034
00:48:08,460 --> 00:48:13,875
Now if this client machine,
if it was on the public network station.

1035
00:48:13,875 --> 00:48:17,566
Then remote desktop would not
be enabled as per these rules.

1036
00:48:17,566 --> 00:48:20,070
>> Yeah, and you'll see that for
each of the remote desktop rules.

1037
00:48:20,070 --> 00:48:22,490
So then you've got
Remote Desktop User Mode and

1038
00:48:22,490 --> 00:48:27,000
then I guess you just have
the four there for User Mode.

1039
00:48:27,000 --> 00:48:31,220
And, you'll see on those where public,
it's turned off, domain, it's turned on.

00:48:31,220 --> 00:48:34,430
So, you may need to tweak those
to get the settings that you need

1041
00:48:34,430 --> 00:48:36,020
to enable that to connect.

00:48:36,020 --> 00:48:36,640
All right.

00:48:36,640 --> 00:48:38,420
So definitely pay attention

1044
00:48:38,420 --> 00:48:41,180
Remember TCP port 3389,
that's what's used by default.

1045
00:48:41,180 --> 00:48:42,770
All right,

1046
00:48:42,770 --> 00:48:45,870
couple other things that we need to think
about with Remote Desktop Protocol.

1047
00:48:45,870 --> 00:48:48,920
If your workstation is
Is behind a NAT router.

1048
00:48:48,920 --> 00:48:51,030
When somebody tries to connect to you,

1049
00:48:51,030 --> 00:48:53,160
they're trying to connect
to your public IP.

1050
00:48:54,420 --> 00:48:56,900
If that public IP is hosted by the router,
and

1051
00:48:56,900 --> 00:49:01,030
you're NATTed behind it, the router
won't know to connect to your client.

1052
00:49:01,030 --> 00:49:05,520
So, you may need to set up port forwarding
to forward port 3389 down to your

1053
00:49:05,520 --> 00:49:06,860
client to connect.

1054
00:49:06,860 --> 00:49:08,910
That's fine if it's just
your machine at home.

1055
00:49:08,910 --> 00:49:10,140
A lot of us do that.

1056
00:49:10,140 --> 00:49:12,130
I do that with my own at home.

1057
00:49:12,130 --> 00:49:13,860
It's fine if you just have one machine.

1058
00:49:13,860 --> 00:49:16,910
But if you're a business, you might
have a hundred, a thousand machines

1059
00:49:16,910 --> 00:49:20,010
that you wanna enable this for and port
forwarding is not an option at that point.

1060
00:49:21,100 --> 00:49:25,090
It's also not an option to assign a static
IP to all of your different clients.

1061
00:49:25,090 --> 00:49:29,924

Remote Desktop Gateway Services.

just straight up Remote Desktop Gateway.

00:49:37,989 --> 00:49:38,628

00:49:38,628 --> 00:49:42,870
So, we can set up a server that

People remote to the server and the server

So while you may not have a direct

1093
00:51:03,530 --> 00:51:06,570

All right?

And basically,
you just put in the server name and

how you want to authenticate against it,

1098
00:51:12,825 --> 00:51:17,900
So let's say it is rd.itpro.tv, right?

00:51:19,020 --> 00:51:23,330
So maybe we've got a server called

00:51:23,330 --> 00:51:25,620
Now somebody would have
to set that server up and

1101

00:51:28,480 --> 00:51:31,611
But you punch that in there, and

All right?

If you leave it to auto,

00:51:50,020 --> 00:51:50,740

00:51:50,740 --> 00:51:52,780
So, we can set that option right there,

00:51:52,780 --> 00:51:57,270

The cool part about using the web

1249
00:58:19,950 --> 00:58:24,100
We kind of read through some if it and
that's really it.

1250
00:58:24,100 --> 00:58:28,200
So the health agent cannot update
the security state, all right, and

1251
00:58:28,200 --> 00:58:32,900
the result's right down there and
it tells us what it is that we need to do.

1252
00:58:32,900 --> 00:58:36,770
So the remediation results,
an administrator must enable a firewall

1253
00:58:36,770 --> 00:58:40,990
program that is compatible with
the Windows Security Center service.

1254
00:58:40,990 --> 00:58:42,640
So there we go.

1255
00:58:42,640 --> 00:58:45,420
>> Yep.
Now, keep in mind if you're the end user,

1256
00:58:45,420 --> 00:58:48,770
you're getting this message,
you're not able to connect to the network.

1257
00:58:48,770 --> 00:58:51,480
You're now in what's called
a remediation network.

1258
00:58:51,480 --> 00:58:53,060
You will show as being on the network.

1259
00:58:53,060 --> 00:58:55,330
You, you know, your network
adapter will show a link light.

1260
00:58:55,330 --> 00:58:57,000
You'll have an IP address.

1261
00:58:57,000 --> 00:59:01,520
But if you start trying to access internal
network resources, you're only gonna

1262
00:59:01,520 --> 00:59:06,392
be able to access what your network
admins have deemed as acceptable, right?

1263
00:59:06,392 --> 00:59:10,470
So, looking at Nate's machine there,
he's got an internal IP.

1264
00:59:10,470 --> 00:59:14,750
But he's now being filtered so
he can only access certain hosts.

1265
00:59:14,750 --> 00:59:17,492
When somebody builds a remediation
network what they normally do is put

1266
00:59:17,492 --> 00:59:19,603
enough servers on there to
be able to fix your problem.

1267
00:59:19,603 --> 00:59:23,635
So if you have a requirement that says
virus definitions have to be up to date,

1268
00:59:23,635 --> 00:59:28,040
then the remediation network will normally
just have access to antivirus servers so

1269
00:59:28,040 --> 00:59:30,180
that we can update our definitions.

1270
00:59:30,180 --> 00:59:30,740
Right?

1271
00:59:30,740 --> 00:59:34,390
Otherwise, you block somebody off and have
no chance of getting onto your network.

1272
00:59:34,390 --> 00:59:35,825
Here they at least have
a chance to make good.

1273
00:59:35,825 --> 00:59:36,410
>> Mm-hm.

1274
00:59:36,410 --> 00:59:38,020
>> Same thing with, like, Windows Updates.

1275
00:59:38,020 --> 00:59:40,800
If we require them to have
done Windows Updates, their

1276
00:59:40,800 --> 00:59:45,270
remediation network might allow them just
access to the Windows Updates website.

1277
00:59:45,270 --> 00:59:48,340
And that way they can do their updates and
become current, all right?

1278
00:59:48,340 --> 00:59:52,620
So, in this case,
Nate's machine is not in compliance, so

1279
00:59:52,620 --> 00:59:55,160
he's getting a message popping
up that's telling him hey,

1280
00:59:55,160 --> 01:00:00,090
Nate you're not allowed to connect and
here's why, your firewall's not turned on.

1281
01:00:00,090 --> 01:00:00,710
Okay?

1282
01:00:00,710 --> 01:00:03,110
So if we turn the firewall back on,
what happens?

1283
01:00:04,560 --> 01:00:05,270
Let's find out.

1284
01:00:06,610 --> 01:00:11,015
>> We'll go in here and we will enable
that firewall so it'll flag down there,

1285
01:00:11,015 --> 01:00:15,110
right, so, it doesn't take very
long at all, it turns from a red x,

1286
01:00:15,110 --> 01:00:17,830
all right, and then sure enough,
so here we go.

1287
01:00:17,830 --> 01:00:20,660
Now this computer meets
the security standards set by

1288
01:00:20,660 --> 01:00:22,050
our network administrator, cool.

1289
01:00:23,600 --> 01:00:27,955
>> So, for the end user, they really
just need to be able to read, right?

1290
01:00:27,955 --> 01:00:31,300
>> [LAUGH]
>> Read that status message that pops up.

1291
01:00:31,300 --> 01:00:37,000
I do want to mention one other thing that
can make NAP do a false block or whatever.

1292
01:00:37,000 --> 01:00:40,950
And that is, in order for
network access protection to work,

1293
01:00:40,950 --> 01:00:44,640
the client has to be able to evaluate
whether it's in compliance or not.

1294
01:00:44,640 --> 01:00:46,500
And it does that through a service.

1295
01:00:46,500 --> 01:00:49,730
Nate, can you bring up your
services administrative tool.

1296
01:00:49,730 --> 01:00:53,245
There is a service that's running
that's called, if I remember right,

1297
01:00:53,245 --> 01:00:55,186
the Network Access Protection Client.

1298
01:00:55,186 --> 01:00:59,806
And if that client is stopped,
right, if somebody's disabled it, or

1299
01:00:59,806 --> 01:01:05,060
whatever, then that's gonna make it where
we can't possibly pass a NAP check.

1300
01:01:05,060 --> 01:01:06,470
We might meet all the requirements.

1301
01:01:06,470 --> 01:01:07,868
We might have done our Windows updates,

1302
01:01:07,868 --> 01:01:10,600
run our antivirus,
have our firewall turned on.

1303
01:01:10,600 --> 01:01:14,609
But if the NAP client is not running to
evaluate it then, then we don't know.

1304
01:01:14,609 --> 01:01:15,130
Right.

1305
01:01:15,130 --> 01:01:16,520
oh, it's called the NAP agent.

1306
01:01:16,520 --> 01:01:18,390
The Network Access Protection Agent.

1307
01:01:18,390 --> 01:01:18,965
I was close.

1308
01:01:18,965 --> 01:01:19,472
>> Mm-hm.

1309
01:01:19,472 --> 01:01:21,840
>> Client agent, whatever, [LAUGH].

1310
01:01:21,840 --> 01:01:25,580
So you can see where Nate's is set
to automatic and it's started.

1311
01:01:25,580 --> 01:01:30,823
If your IT department has turned on NAP,
they've probably written a policy that

1312
01:01:30,823 --> 01:01:35,853
says, manually, or automatically turn
on this process and get it running.

1313
01:01:35,853 --> 01:01:39,319
But if this is a new deployment,
if you've got machines that aren't

1314
01:01:39,319 --> 01:01:43,470
joined to your domain, they don't have to
be joined to the domain for NAP to work.

1315
01:01:43,470 --> 01:01:45,263
If that's the case,
you may need to come and

1316
01:01:45,263 --> 01:01:48,186
start this and not just start it
because it's set to manual by default.

1317
01:01:48,186 --> 01:01:51,070
So if you just start it, the next
time you reboot it will be off again.

1318
01:01:51,070 --> 01:01:53,040
So you really need to change to automatic.

1319
01:01:53,040 --> 01:01:54,764
Tell it to start up automatically,

1320
01:01:54,764 --> 01:01:57,870
that way we're able to communicate
with NAP boxes, all right?

1321
01:01:57,870 --> 01:02:01,220
Now Nate, do you remember,
cuz I'm not sure that I do,

1322
01:02:01,220 --> 01:02:05,890
the NAP agent itself was introduced
in Vista if I remember correctly.

1323
01:02:05,890 --> 01:02:09,750
And if you're running an earlier operating
system than that like Windows XP it

1324
01:02:09,750 --> 01:02:12,810
doesn't have the NAP agent on it and
you have to install it.

1325
01:02:12,810 --> 01:02:15,350
So you can get that from
the Windows Server machine or

1326
01:02:15,350 --> 01:02:16,580
whatever to install it on there.

1327
01:02:16,580 --> 01:02:19,240
But Windows 8, what's on the exam,
it's got it built in.

1328
01:02:19,240 --> 01:02:20,030
We just have to turn it on.

1329
01:02:20,030 --> 01:02:22,010
>> Mm-hm, yeah you know,

1330
01:02:22,010 --> 01:02:27,610
on the network configuration you see
that when we were not in compliance.

1331
01:02:27,610 --> 01:02:29,792
So it,
it moved me into that remediation network.

1332
01:02:29,792 --> 01:02:33,740
So it's, so changing here it
took away the gateway here.

1333
01:02:33,740 --> 01:02:37,290
And on the server side there is that
remediation network that's set up,

1334
01:02:37,290 --> 01:02:42,930
that when this policy kicks in,
you can only talk to these guys over here.

1335
01:02:42,930 --> 01:02:46,410
And we can see a period, restricted.net so

1336
01:02:46,410 --> 01:02:48,800
we know that we're in
that remediation network.

1337
01:02:48,800 --> 01:02:54,190
After we fixed it, and ran good old IP
config again, we see it gave me that

1338
01:02:54,190 --> 01:02:58,040
gateway back, and it put me back
in our regular business network.

1339
01:02:58,040 --> 01:02:59,990
Here we are back in class.

1340
01:02:59,990 --> 01:03:04,100
>> And so he's got the same IP,
it was 10.10.5.221 both times.

1341
01:03:04,100 --> 01:03:07,432
So NAP has special filtering that
interacts with the operating system to

1342
01:03:07,432 --> 01:03:08,312
block that stuff.

1343
01:03:08,312 --> 01:03:11,145
And the subnet mask and
default gateway populating so yeah.

1344
01:03:11,145 --> 01:03:15,420
Now he gets that full access all being
controlled by the protection servers.

1345
01:03:15,420 --> 01:03:18,960
It's a great idea, especially in this
bring your own device age, right?

1346
01:03:18,960 --> 01:03:21,700
Where people are bringing their
own laptops and stuff from home.

1347
01:03:21,700 --> 01:03:25,890
NAP gives us the ability to say,
are you taking care of your machines?

1348
01:03:25,890 --> 01:03:30,010
Are you doing the proper preventative
methods to ensure that you're not getting

1349
01:03:30,010 --> 01:03:34,500
infected and getting spyware and all
that other crazy stuff on your machine.

1350
01:03:34,500 --> 01:03:35,350
We can enforce that.

1351
01:03:35,350 --> 01:03:36,440
So really cool stuff.

1352
01:03:36,440 --> 01:03:37,000
>> Mm-hm.

1353
01:03:37,000 --> 01:03:39,310
Yeah.
Now there are some commands on there,

1354
01:03:39,310 --> 01:03:45,300
that we can kind of view the status so
we can see what is being pushed out to us.

1355
01:03:45,300 --> 01:03:47,470
And those are good old netsh commands.

1356
01:03:47,470 --> 01:03:49,310
Don, do you remember all of your netsh?

1357
01:03:49,310 --> 01:03:50,700
>> Oh, of course I got them memorized.

1358
01:03:50,700 --> 01:03:51,268
I use them every day.

1359
01:03:51,268 --> 01:03:52,186
>> Right?

1360
01:03:52,186 --> 01:03:55,728
>> [LAUGH] > The first command
is www.google.com [LAUGH]

1361
01:03:55,728 --> 01:04:00,229
>> [LAUGH]

1362
01:04:00,229 --> 01:04:02,432
>> All right, so we've got netsh,

1363
01:04:02,432 --> 01:04:04,770
nat client, show state.

1364
01:04:04,770 --> 01:04:07,760
Right, so show me what state we're in.

1365
01:04:07,760 --> 01:04:12,077
So it spits some of
the stuff out right here.

1366
01:04:13,460 --> 01:04:17,330
And we can dig through and
see what's being pushed out.

1367
01:04:17,330 --> 01:04:23,685
Now, as far how NAP is being enforced,
we do have a couple of ways.

1368
01:04:23,685 --> 01:04:26,873
DHCP, so we can enforce it by DHCP.

1369
01:04:26,873 --> 01:04:32,860
And the next one down so DCB is set to
yes and is being enforced that way.

1370
01:04:32,860 --> 01:04:36,350
We can enforce it through an IP SACK,
remote desktop gateway.

1371
01:04:36,350 --> 01:04:38,140
All the stuff here is set to no.

1372
01:04:38,140 --> 01:04:42,150
You may say well, okay, well what
aspect of it is it being pushed out.

1373
01:04:42,150 --> 01:04:45,240
So we're gonna see that right there.

1374
01:04:45,240 --> 01:04:46,720
Mm.
And there is another one.

1375
01:04:46,720 --> 01:04:51,142
Instead of show state, show config.

1376
01:04:51,142 --> 01:04:55,370
Once again, same kind of things,
we can see what is being enabled.

1377
01:04:55,370 --> 01:04:56,100
Or disabled.

1378
01:04:57,150 --> 01:05:03,482
And then there is also,
it's another little tool that we can use.

1379
01:05:03,482 --> 01:05:11,478
[NOISE] Napclientconfig.msc.

1380
01:05:11,478 --> 01:05:13,709
All right so this right here is a,

1381
01:05:13,709 --> 01:05:17,634
this little configuration tool
that is runs client side.

1382
01:05:17,634 --> 01:05:20,075
Oops [LAUGH].

1383
01:05:20,075 --> 01:05:22,180
I'll just get back this guy.

1384
01:05:22,180 --> 01:05:23,040
Stretch it out a little bit.

1385
01:05:25,120 --> 01:05:26,910
And here we can make some changes.

1386
01:05:26,910 --> 01:05:30,290
If it wasn't being enforced by policy.

1387
01:05:30,290 --> 01:05:34,630
I mean you see some things in
here in the enforcement clients.

1388
01:05:36,340 --> 01:05:38,680
These are those different things so
we saw in the command line.

1389
01:05:38,680 --> 01:05:42,780
So which ways is NAT being pushed out?

1390
01:05:42,780 --> 01:05:46,420
When you see that just the DHCP
one is being utilized so

1391
01:05:46,420 --> 01:05:48,700
whenever this machine goes and reaches for

1392
01:05:48,700 --> 01:05:53,230
that DHCP address, it makes sure that
this guy here is communicating properly.

1393
01:05:53,230 --> 01:05:56,400
And then there's all
those other ones there.

1394
01:05:56,400 --> 01:05:59,640
And interface settings, so
that that little pop up that we got.

1395
01:05:59,640 --> 01:06:01,382
>> Mm-hm.
>> That showed we weren't here.

1396
01:06:01,382 --> 01:06:06,340
We can modify that and
put little pictures or custom text.

1397
01:06:06,340 --> 01:06:11,940
And those sorts of things in there on
the health registration settings here.

1398
01:06:11,940 --> 01:06:15,217
Which of course on the clients side I
don't have anything configured here.

1399
01:06:16,910 --> 01:06:20,020
>> Yeah, there's a lot to it you know for
the most part though,

1400
01:06:20,020 --> 01:06:22,470
the dream of NAP, right?

1401
01:06:22,470 --> 01:06:25,155
That we try and achieve is where
it's all pushed out by policy.

1402
01:06:25,155 --> 01:06:25,920
>> Mm-hm.
>> And so

1403
01:06:25,920 --> 01:06:28,310
there's not a whole lot of room for error.

1404
01:06:28,310 --> 01:06:30,140
I think pretty much the things
that Nate showed originally.

1405
01:06:30,140 --> 01:06:33,890
The making sure that service is started
and making sure that you're in compliance.

1406
01:06:33,890 --> 01:06:35,420
Those are things that we need to do.

1407
01:06:35,420 --> 01:06:38,000
On the server side, there's a ton of
things that can go wrong, though, so

1408
01:06:38,000 --> 01:06:38,900
if you wanna see more of that,

1409
01:06:38,900 --> 01:06:43,480
definitely jump over and check out the
7410 show where we set up, or 7411 show.

1410
01:06:43,480 --> 01:06:44,375
>> Yep, Nap is 411.

1411
01:06:44,375 --> 01:06:45,548
>> 411, 7411 show.

1412
01:06:45,548 --> 01:06:48,479
>> Mm-hm.
>> One of the Windows server 2012 R2 shows

1413
01:06:48,479 --> 01:06:50,240
and we show up how to set up NAP.

1414
01:06:50,240 --> 01:06:52,560
Because there's like five
different ways to set it up.

1415
01:06:52,560 --> 01:06:55,870
Each one tailored to a different need or

1416
01:06:55,870 --> 01:06:58,380
whatever so
definitely something worth checking out.

1417
01:06:58,380 --> 01:07:00,345
It's neat stuff, it really is.

1418
01:07:00,345 --> 01:07:02,970
Alright so Nate I think that
pretty much raps this up.

1419
01:07:02,970 --> 01:07:06,440
As far as we did VPN's,
we did RDP and we did NAP and

1420
01:07:06,440 --> 01:07:10,070
that's pretty much, now are remote
services that we need to be aware of,

1421
01:07:10,070 --> 01:07:14,185
as far as trouble shooting and
maintaining those, that's pretty much it.

1422
01:07:14,185 --> 01:07:16,410
>> Mm-hm.
>> Anything else to throw in?

1423
01:07:16,410 --> 01:07:18,192
>> No, that's it.

1424
01:07:18,192 --> 01:07:18,950
Of course,

1425
01:07:18,950 --> 01:07:22,730
all the stock fell off the back end and
there's a lot of things on the backside.

1426
01:07:22,730 --> 01:07:25,950
And as you mention,
there's a lot more interested and

1427
01:07:25,950 --> 01:07:29,270
jump into those other shows, and,
yeah, check out the nitty gritty,

1428
01:07:29,270 --> 01:07:32,080
set the stuff up in a home lab and
mess around with it.

1429
01:07:32,080 --> 01:07:33,530
>> Yeah, that's really where
you have the fun, right?

1430
01:07:33,530 --> 01:07:34,410
You set it up in a lab.

1431
01:07:34,410 --> 01:07:37,911
Cuz that's where you truly get to see all
the things that can go wrong [LAUGH].

1432
01:07:37,911 --> 01:07:41,200
Alright, well, ladies and gentlemen,
hope you guys enjoyed the show.

1433
01:07:41,200 --> 01:07:44,920
Let me just remind you, live, during the
show, feel free to give us your questions.

1434
01:07:44,920 --> 01:07:47,930
Go to itpro.tv/live,
you'll see the chat box.

1435
01:07:47,930 --> 01:07:49,200
Right beneath the video.

1436
01:07:49,200 --> 01:07:50,240
Just throw your questions in there.

1437
01:07:50,240 --> 01:07:52,470
We monitor and answer during the show.

1438
01:07:52,470 --> 01:07:56,590
If you have questions after the show, use
the Q and A link at the top of the page.

1439
01:07:56,590 --> 01:08:02,140
If you go to itpro.tv/, well no,
just itpro.tv anything, right?

1440
01:08:02,140 --> 01:08:03,090
Any of our websites.

1441
01:08:03,090 --> 01:08:04,960
There's that link that says Q and
A at the top.

1442
01:08:04,960 --> 01:08:07,120
It'll take you right into our Q and
A forum.

1443
01:08:07,120 --> 01:08:07,930
Post your questions there.

1444
01:08:07,930 --> 01:08:08,510
We monitor and

1445
01:08:08,510 --> 01:08:12,060
answer, and we make sure you guys get
the the information that you need.

1446
01:08:12,060 --> 01:08:13,560
So take advantage of that resource.

1447
01:08:13,560 --> 01:08:15,280
It is there for you.

1448
01:08:15,280 --> 01:08:17,820
Alright well signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

1449
01:08:17,820 --> 01:08:19,380
>> And I'm Nathan Copeland.

1450
01:08:19,380 --> 01:08:20,770
>> And we'll see you next time.

1451
01:08:20,770 --> 01:08:30,770
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Ronnie discuss and demonstrate the usage of tools and utilities to help support client compliance.  They go into the individual utilites to configure them as well as show how compliance is set through local group policies and Windows Intune.
episodes.title: Support Client Compliance
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,775 --> 00:00:38,109
All right, welcome back to another
fantastic episode of IT Pro TV.

3

I am Nathan Copeland
here with Ronnie Wong.

4

6
00:00:44,310 --> 00:00:45,790

I'm doing very well.

7
00:00:45,790 --> 00:00:48,320

>> Yes, yes, I'm doing very well.

8
00:00:48,320 --> 00:00:53,140
>> Better than, better than I don't know,
what are you fishing for?

9
00:00:53,140 --> 00:00:54,000
Oh no.

10
00:00:54,000 --> 00:00:56,040
>> It was what, yeah,
one of those interest stories?

11
00:00:56,040 --> 00:00:58,570
>> Yeah, no I was just gonna
ask you how it went with

12
00:00:58,570 --> 00:01:01,500

13
00:01:02,625 --> 00:01:04,400

00:01:11,940 --> 00:01:14,551

18
00:01:14,551 --> 00:01:16,940
And [LAUGH] there we go.

19
00:01:16,940 --> 00:01:17,700

20

And this is where Nate, was going with the

there's a process to the way

So Nate mentioned a ticker

1872

01:40:42,920 --> 01:40:46,140

in the active directory group policy,

01:40:49,960 --> 01:40:52,930

1877
01:40:52,930 --> 01:40:56,260

a domain level?

1878
01:40:56,260 --> 01:40:59,350
Well, it's actually about
the last one that applies.

1879
01:40:59,350 --> 01:41:06,660
So the order is local, site, domain, and
then another organization we call an OU.

1880
01:41:06,660 --> 01:41:10,860
So it actually applies in that order.

1881
01:41:10,860 --> 01:41:15,180
Local applies first, then site,
then domain, and then OU.

1882
01:41:15,180 --> 01:41:18,520
So if I have one policy that
applies at the local level.

1883
01:41:18,520 --> 01:41:24,460
But then, I have the same policy with
different settings applying in the domain.

01:41:24,460 --> 01:41:26,000

1885
01:41:26,000 --> 01:41:27,600

1886
01:41:27,600 --> 01:41:28,870

1888
01:41:30,955 --> 01:41:34,380
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's because it was applied last.

1889
01:41:34,380 --> 01:41:36,930
So it's whichever one's
applied last that will happen.

1890
01:41:36,930 --> 01:41:41,470

01:41:41,470 --> 01:41:45,020

also have to actually understand,

is there another policy

01:41:58,370 --> 01:41:59,599
Now.

a like a performance to help out-

It can take a long time for Nate,
to just get logged into the computer.

1914

hey the first time that you do it,

01:42:58,810 --> 01:43:03,080

that now when Nate logs in again,
instead of actually go and

01:43:05,940 --> 01:43:07,970

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Ronnie demonstrate the use of Windows Intune to manage users and devices from cloud based management services. They describe and show how to create users and add computers to the service as well as look at other Intune management possibilities.

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Ronnie discuss supporting mobile devices within business setting.  They use Windows Intune show how a business can integrate BYODs without being part of a Microsoft domain network. They demonstrate using not only Windows Intune but also Sync settings with Offline Files and Work Folders to allow users access to files even while a Windows 8.1 computer is not within the business LAN.

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don take a look at using Recovery tools built into Windows 8.1 Operating System.  They show and demonstrate the use of some of the most common tools such as Task Manager, Device Manager and discuss the scenarios in which we might choose them.  They also show the usage of the enterprise tool found on MDOP (Microsoft Deployment Operations and Planning Kit) called the DaRT (Diagnostic and Recovery Toolkit) for the purpose of diagnosing a computer that will not even startup after a failure.
