00:00:50,506 --> 00:00:52,078
[LAUGH] None.

14
00:00:52,078 --> 00:00:55,720
Not a heavy Asian
representation on Mad Men.

15
00:00:55,720 --> 00:00:58,830
Yeah, for some reason or another,
nobody saw my particular

16
00:00:58,830 --> 00:01:01,405
appearance on there as I try to
make my way into the boardroom.

17
00:01:01,405 --> 00:01:05,150
[LAUGH] So there it is.

18
00:01:05,150 --> 00:01:08,440
Did you have a full 60s outfit?

19
00:01:08,440 --> 00:01:09,135
Oh absolutely.

20
00:01:09,135 --> 00:01:09,850
[LAUGH] Yeah.
Or 50s?

21
00:01:09,850 --> 00:01:11,250
What year is this?

22
00:01:11,250 --> 00:01:11,935
Oh who knows?

23
00:01:11,935 --> 00:01:12,900
[LAUGH] All right.

24
00:01:12,900 --> 00:01:16,820
Well, today we've got a neat episode ahead
of us because we're gonna be tackling

25
00:01:16,820 --> 00:01:22,260
probably one of the more frustrating
parts of being an IT professional,

26
00:01:22,260 --> 00:01:26,550
which is hey, Windows 8's great,
when it works the way it's supposed to.

27
00:01:26,550 --> 00:01:27,110
Sure.

28
00:01:27,110 --> 00:01:30,250
But what do we do when things aren't
working the way they're supposed to?

29
00:01:30,250 --> 00:01:32,810
When things are just breaking,
we're getting errors.

30
00:01:32,810 --> 00:01:35,680
What do we do with that information
that most people ignore,

31
00:01:35,680 --> 00:01:37,310
that we can actually
use to find a problem?

32
00:01:37,310 --> 00:01:37,910
Yeah.

33
00:01:37,910 --> 00:01:40,490
A lot of time,
when we start talking about this, right?

34
00:01:40,490 --> 00:01:43,485
In the early days of operating systems,
there was a lot of frustration,

35
00:01:43,485 --> 00:01:45,900
cuz there wasn't really a lot
of information out there.

36
00:01:45,900 --> 00:01:50,460
But now with Microsoft again introducing
XP and going all the way up through

37
00:01:50,460 --> 00:01:54,480
Windows 8 now, time and time again
they've kept improving on the tools.

38
00:01:54,480 --> 00:01:58,150
And I have to say it, in Windows 8.1
we've actually got a whole suite of tools

39
00:01:58,150 --> 00:02:01,760
that are available to us and
also, the operating system is,

40
00:02:01,760 --> 00:02:05,590
I'm not gonna say it's indestructible but
it actually does give us so

41
00:02:05,590 --> 00:02:09,410
much more that we can actually work with
today, to really be able to isolate what

42
00:02:09,410 --> 00:02:12,820
the problems are and then to actually
have a whole suite of tools behind us

43
00:02:12,820 --> 00:02:15,880
that we can use without having to go
out and buy a lot of third party tools.

44
00:02:15,880 --> 00:02:18,467
So it really is an amazing
operating system in that sense.

45
00:02:18,467 --> 00:02:22,207
All right, so lets start out simple,
with some basic troubleshooting steps and

46
00:02:22,207 --> 00:02:25,397
processes and then we'll get a little
more advanced, as we move on,

47
00:02:25,397 --> 00:02:27,547
and we're gonna show
some really cool stuff.

48
00:02:27,547 --> 00:02:31,830
So, the first thing I wanna do, is I want
to touch base on the Device Manager.

49
00:02:31,830 --> 00:02:36,220
Now, this is something we covered
in the 7687 exam and show, so

50
00:02:36,220 --> 00:02:39,660
you guys should already be familiar
with it, but just to kind of recap.

51
00:02:39,660 --> 00:02:42,770
If you have some hardware that is not
functioning, you've got a printer,

52
00:02:42,770 --> 00:02:44,400
and it's not showing up in the system.

53
00:02:44,400 --> 00:02:48,130
You've got a network adapter and
you're not getting an IP address,

54
00:02:48,130 --> 00:02:48,740
these kind of things.

55
00:02:48,740 --> 00:02:51,210
You've got hardware type issues.

56
00:02:51,210 --> 00:02:53,520
One of the first places that
I go is the Device Manager.

57
00:02:53,520 --> 00:02:56,060
And, you know, this is one
where I practice what I preach,

58
00:02:56,060 --> 00:02:57,761
I actually had this
happen just last night.

59
00:02:57,761 --> 00:03:01,745
[LAUGH] So, just last night on my computer
at home, I plugged in my headphones,

60
00:03:01,745 --> 00:03:06,140
cuz I was about to watch a little
tutorial, and I put on my headset and

61
00:03:06,140 --> 00:03:07,340
I couldn't hear anything.

62
00:03:07,340 --> 00:03:08,890
I said, what the heck's going on here?

63
00:03:08,890 --> 00:03:12,380
So I unplugged the headphone, plugged
it back in, couldn't hear anything,

64
00:03:12,380 --> 00:03:15,960
went into my Device Manager and
the problem was right there.

65
00:03:15,960 --> 00:03:18,640
Let me just pull up the Device Manager
here on my laptop, and

66
00:03:18,640 --> 00:03:22,510
everything should be running fine on my
laptop right now, but when you go into

67
00:03:22,510 --> 00:03:26,250
your Device Manager, and there's ten
different ways to get into here,

68
00:03:26,250 --> 00:03:30,360
I usually just use the start screen and
type device and it turns up pretty quick.

69
00:03:30,360 --> 00:03:34,480
But you can right click on this computer
and choose manage and get in there.

70
00:03:34,480 --> 00:03:35,750
Windows key x- Oh yeah?

71
00:03:35,750 --> 00:03:38,160
Has the short cut to get right
into the Device Manager.

72
00:03:38,160 --> 00:03:41,600
But once you're in there,
it lists all your hardware.

73
00:03:41,600 --> 00:03:45,050
And Windows does something really neat,
which is if there's any exceptions,

74
00:03:45,050 --> 00:03:48,690
any bizarre statuses of your hardware,

75
00:03:48,690 --> 00:03:53,310
it will automatically expand out
the tree item so that you can see that.

76
00:03:53,310 --> 00:03:57,230
And there's usually three that we're
looking for, three bizarre statuses,

77
00:03:57,230 --> 00:04:00,380
or statusi, or
whatever the plural of status is.

78
00:04:00,380 --> 00:04:05,156
One is one that I'm seeing right here on
my Cisco systems VPN adaptor, all right?

79
00:04:05,156 --> 00:04:09,208
You'll notice the white circle with
a black arrow pointing down on it, right?

80
00:04:09,208 --> 00:04:13,401
That's telling me this device is disabled,
all right?

81
00:04:13,401 --> 00:04:17,384
That's a warning note to me saying,
it's not that there's a problem with this

82
00:04:17,384 --> 00:04:19,900
hardware, it's that
somebody's disabled it.

83
00:04:19,900 --> 00:04:21,360
On a VPN adapter like this,

84
00:04:21,360 --> 00:04:25,160
that's a virtual network adapter,
I expect to see this, all right?

85
00:04:25,160 --> 00:04:30,120
When I'm not using the VPN, the Cisco
software disables that connector.

86
00:04:30,120 --> 00:04:34,280
The instant I build up a VPN,
it'll turn this adapter on so

87
00:04:34,280 --> 00:04:35,580
this one comes and goes.

88
00:04:35,580 --> 00:04:39,840
On normal hardware you would not expect
to see the black down arrow, right?

89
00:04:39,840 --> 00:04:43,990
That usually means that somebody manually
disabled that hardware, all right?

90
00:04:43,990 --> 00:04:47,826
Take for example,
I'm using a USB mouse right now, right?

91
00:04:47,826 --> 00:04:53,890
And so if I go in here to mice, I can find
my Logitech HID-compliant unifying mouse.

92
00:04:53,890 --> 00:04:55,720
That's my mouse, right?

93
00:04:55,720 --> 00:05:00,308
And if I disable that, okay so
I'm just gonna disable it, and

94
00:05:00,308 --> 00:05:02,705
I can't move my mouse anymore.

95
00:05:02,705 --> 00:05:04,968
So there goes the mouse, right?

96
00:05:04,968 --> 00:05:07,990
So you don't normally expect to see this.

97
00:05:07,990 --> 00:05:09,850
It's a manual thing.

98
00:05:09,850 --> 00:05:10,681
Somebody had to do it.

99
00:05:10,681 --> 00:05:14,599
I have a touchpad also, so I'm switching
over to my terrible touchpad and

100
00:05:14,599 --> 00:05:17,392
I'll turn that back on and
my mouse will work again.

101
00:05:17,392 --> 00:05:18,055
There we go.

102
00:05:18,055 --> 00:05:22,196
So that one's not really a random problem
that's gonna suddenly kick in, right?

103
00:05:22,196 --> 00:05:24,790
That's usually something
we've created ourselves.

104
00:05:24,790 --> 00:05:28,140
With hardware devices here,
right, it is not disabled.

105
00:05:28,140 --> 00:05:31,350
You might also end up
seeing a yellow triangle or

106
00:05:31,350 --> 00:05:33,070
a yellow question mark at times.

107
00:05:33,070 --> 00:05:36,360
And sometimes that actually indicates for
us, especially if you see a question mark,

108
00:05:36,360 --> 00:05:38,760
is that hey look,
I know that there is a device there,

109
00:05:38,760 --> 00:05:40,740
but Windows just can't see it.

110
00:05:40,740 --> 00:05:42,730
So you might be missing
a device driver so.

111
00:05:42,730 --> 00:05:43,886
Yeah, usually that's it.

112
00:05:43,886 --> 00:05:44,728
The device driver, right?

113
00:05:44,728 --> 00:05:48,640
If you plug in hardware that Windows
doesn't recognize, if it doesn't know that

114
00:05:48,640 --> 00:05:52,392
driver, WIndows has a ton of drivers
built in but it doesn't have all of them.

115
00:05:52,392 --> 00:05:54,626
And so you'll get the yellow triangle.

116
00:05:54,626 --> 00:05:57,389
It's a yellow triangle with
a back exclamation point in it.

117
00:05:57,389 --> 00:05:58,272
That's it.

118
00:05:58,272 --> 00:06:00,220
And that's your big warning.

119
00:06:00,220 --> 00:06:03,790
I've also seen it with USB devices
sometimes though, for whatever reason,

120
00:06:03,790 --> 00:06:07,430
it doesn't recognize the device and all
you have to do is unplug the device and

121
00:06:07,430 --> 00:06:11,100
plug it into a different USB port,
and it recognizes it and it's happy.

122
00:06:11,100 --> 00:06:15,190
So that can happen sometimes, and
you don't have to load a driver.

123
00:06:15,190 --> 00:06:17,720
But more often or not,
it just means you're missing a driver,

124
00:06:17,720 --> 00:06:21,090
you need to go out to that vendor's
website, download the driver, and load it.

125
00:06:21,090 --> 00:06:23,583
Now Don, have you ever had the problem
where you updated a driver and

126
00:06:23,583 --> 00:06:26,183
all of a sudden the device didn't work
the same way that you need it to?

127
00:06:26,183 --> 00:06:27,958
Yeah.
[LAUGH] Yeah that happens,

128
00:06:27,958 --> 00:06:28,700
unfortunately often.

129
00:06:30,310 --> 00:06:33,900
Drivers introduce change, and sometimes
change is good, sometimes change is bad,

130
00:06:33,900 --> 00:06:36,240
and a lot of times in drivers,
it could really cause problems.

131
00:06:36,240 --> 00:06:38,400
I see that with video cards mostly.

132
00:06:38,400 --> 00:06:42,132
The latest update for
a video card comes out, you apply it, and

133
00:06:42,132 --> 00:06:45,175
all of a sudden you get overheats or
weird reboots.

134
00:06:45,175 --> 00:06:46,960
And they fix the problem soon enough, but

135
00:06:46,960 --> 00:06:49,880
what do you do while you're waiting
on that fix to come out, right?

136
00:06:49,880 --> 00:06:54,208
So in the 7687 show,
we tackled how to do driver rollbacks and

137
00:06:54,208 --> 00:06:56,960
how to interact with those drivers.

138
00:06:56,960 --> 00:06:59,370
So, keep in mind that
that's all available and

139
00:06:59,370 --> 00:07:02,190
jump over to the 7687
show to fill in on that.

140
00:07:02,190 --> 00:07:05,530
What we're more concerned with here
is knowing when that's appropriate.

141
00:07:05,530 --> 00:07:08,860
Driver rollbacks are tricky because
when you look in your Device Manager,

142
00:07:08,860 --> 00:07:11,335
your device, it'll look normal.

143
00:07:11,335 --> 00:07:13,100
Mm-hm.
It won't have any exceptional

144
00:07:13,100 --> 00:07:14,380
status on it.

145
00:07:14,380 --> 00:07:16,910
And, let me just zoom in a bit here.

146
00:07:16,910 --> 00:07:18,445
I'm gonna go double mouse on us again.

147
00:07:18,445 --> 00:07:21,090
But, it'll look normal like this

148
00:07:21,090 --> 00:07:22,830
because Windows doesn't think
there's something wrong.

149
00:07:22,830 --> 00:07:24,750
It just has the newer driver, right.

150
00:07:24,750 --> 00:07:26,750
But we can always choose to roll it back.

151
00:07:26,750 --> 00:07:30,000
I don't know if have any,
do I have any drivers to rollback to?

152
00:07:30,000 --> 00:07:30,970
No.
So, yeah,

153
00:07:30,970 --> 00:07:32,980
I'm still running my original driver here.

154
00:07:32,980 --> 00:07:37,570
But if you've just done an update, you'll
see that little gray button there will

155
00:07:37,570 --> 00:07:40,451
actually be colored so that you can
click on it and rollback to it.

156
00:07:41,730 --> 00:07:44,890
All right, the only other status I've
ever seen in here is the red circle with

157
00:07:44,890 --> 00:07:45,670
the white x in it.

158
00:07:45,670 --> 00:07:47,380
[LAUGH] Hopefully you don't see that one.

159
00:07:47,380 --> 00:07:50,872
That indicates that there is some
kind of actual failure on the cards.

160
00:07:50,872 --> 00:07:52,093
Because this is hardware,

161
00:07:52,093 --> 00:07:55,284
normally if you have a true failure
like that the card just disappears.

162
00:07:55,284 --> 00:07:57,590
It just doesn't even show
up in the Device Manager.

163
00:07:57,590 --> 00:08:01,674
I had that happen with a network adapter
once, where The network adapter just died.

164
00:08:01,674 --> 00:08:03,525
Yeah.
The circuitry on it had a popped

165
00:08:03,525 --> 00:08:04,270
capacitor.

166
00:08:05,430 --> 00:08:07,200
Looking at the card,
you could see that popped- Yeah.

167
00:08:07,200 --> 00:08:10,410
Capacitor right on it, but
inside the computer you couldn't.

168
00:08:10,410 --> 00:08:12,750
It just made the card not
receive enough power.

169
00:08:12,750 --> 00:08:13,696
It didn't even show up
in the Device Manager.

170
00:08:13,696 --> 00:08:14,450
Right.

171
00:08:14,450 --> 00:08:16,230
So that's what you'll normally see there.

172
00:08:16,230 --> 00:08:20,010
Yeah, the good thing is, this is one place
that we can actually really use to help us

173
00:08:20,010 --> 00:08:24,310
to pinpoint what particular hardware
issue We're really taking a look at here.

174
00:08:24,310 --> 00:08:27,410
And this should be actually kind
of near the top of our list when

175
00:08:27,410 --> 00:08:30,650
we begin the idea of troubleshooting,
especially with hardware.

176
00:08:30,650 --> 00:08:35,631
Now, unfortunately with hardware issues,
user applications our regular

177
00:08:35,631 --> 00:08:39,537
user space stuff is not allowed
to touch hardware, right?

178
00:08:39,537 --> 00:08:41,280
Right.
We have to go through the hardware

179
00:08:41,280 --> 00:08:44,400
abstraction layer,
which is part of the Windows core OS.

180
00:08:44,400 --> 00:08:48,770
And the HAL or hardware abstraction layer,
that's what's allowed to reach out and

181
00:08:48,770 --> 00:08:49,830
touch the hardware.

182
00:08:49,830 --> 00:08:52,730
So if something goes
wrong with the hardware,

183
00:08:52,730 --> 00:08:54,940
it's happening not in user space- Right.

184
00:08:54,940 --> 00:08:56,460
But in kernel space.

185
00:08:56,460 --> 00:08:59,445
And that means a failure in kernel
space is gonna be far worse than,

186
00:08:59,445 --> 00:09:01,742
like if- Right.

187
00:09:01,742 --> 00:09:02,750
Google Chrome- Yeah.

188
00:09:02,750 --> 00:09:05,910
Crashes for me,
I don't have to reboot my computer.

189
00:09:05,910 --> 00:09:09,075
But if we have a hardware failure kernel
space you're normally gonna have to

190
00:09:09,075 --> 00:09:10,762
reboot, they're critical problems.

191
00:09:10,762 --> 00:09:11,370
Right.

192
00:09:11,370 --> 00:09:14,432
And that's where we start to get
what are called stop errors.

193
00:09:14,432 --> 00:09:16,443
Right.
So let's talk about stop errors for

194
00:09:16,443 --> 00:09:16,962
a minute.

195
00:09:16,962 --> 00:09:18,390
Yeah.
Now stop errors.

196
00:09:18,390 --> 00:09:19,987
A lot of us know them by their old name.

197
00:09:19,987 --> 00:09:23,415
[LAUGH] The BSOD or blue screen of death.

198
00:09:23,415 --> 00:09:26,170
In the olden days- Right.

199
00:09:26,170 --> 00:09:29,050
When Windows had a kernel space
failure that the base just

200
00:09:29,050 --> 00:09:30,960
freaked out the whole operating system.

201
00:09:30,960 --> 00:09:34,452
Your screen would turn blue, and
then in either white or gray text,

202
00:09:34,452 --> 00:09:36,690
depending on the OS- Yeah.

203
00:09:36,690 --> 00:09:39,030
You would then get a memory dump.

204
00:09:39,030 --> 00:09:41,060
Right.
It would tell you the module that failed,

205
00:09:41,060 --> 00:09:43,610
which might be meaningful, it might not.

206
00:09:43,610 --> 00:09:47,560
And then just a huge list of hexadecimal
characters spread across the screen

207
00:09:47,560 --> 00:09:51,560
that were identifying what was in
RAM at the point when it crashed.

208
00:09:51,560 --> 00:09:52,810
Right?

209
00:09:52,810 --> 00:09:54,760
To end users, what does that information?

210
00:09:54,760 --> 00:09:56,120
What does that information mean to you,
Ronnie?

211
00:09:56,120 --> 00:09:57,490
It meant nothing to me except for

212
00:09:57,490 --> 00:10:00,210
a bunch of hexadecimal numbers that
I had no clue what they were about.

213
00:10:00,210 --> 00:10:01,370
Yep.
Yeah.

214
00:10:01,370 --> 00:10:06,020
And Microsoft isn't the only company
that does this, other OS's do it too.

215
00:10:06,020 --> 00:10:08,560
Some of them got a little
smarter early one, like Apple.

216
00:10:08,560 --> 00:10:12,332
Apple said look, our end-users they don't
need a memory dump- [LAUGH] That doesn't

217
00:10:12,332 --> 00:10:12,960
mean anything to them.

218
00:10:12,960 --> 00:10:13,832
So what do they get?

219
00:10:13,832 --> 00:10:14,948
They get the sad mac, right?

220
00:10:14,948 --> 00:10:17,615
[LAUGH] The little mac appears on
the screen, it's got a frowney face.

221
00:10:17,615 --> 00:10:18,826
Yeah.
And x's for it's eyes, and

222
00:10:18,826 --> 00:10:20,330
then the computer reboots.

223
00:10:20,330 --> 00:10:21,266
Why bother showing them the memory dump?

224
00:10:21,266 --> 00:10:22,250
Right.

225
00:10:22,250 --> 00:10:24,250
And Microsoft has finally
gone that way too.

226
00:10:24,250 --> 00:10:25,450
They said do you know what?

227
00:10:25,450 --> 00:10:28,070
There is no point in showing
the memory dump to our end user.

228
00:10:28,070 --> 00:10:30,240
So instead we're gonna show a blue screen.

229
00:10:30,240 --> 00:10:31,070
Yeah.
It is still blue.

230
00:10:31,070 --> 00:10:32,477
It's a different blue now- Right.

231
00:10:32,477 --> 00:10:33,400
But it is still blue.

232
00:10:33,400 --> 00:10:35,390
And it's got a little frowny face on it.

233
00:10:35,390 --> 00:10:39,370
Yeah, it's the sideways frowny face, so
when you do the emoticon kinda thing.

234
00:10:39,370 --> 00:10:40,850
Let me see if I can
find a picture of this.

235
00:10:40,850 --> 00:10:43,280
Yeah, it's kind of unusual, right?

236
00:10:43,280 --> 00:10:48,490
But because Microsoft has been heading
more towards that unified kind of device,

237
00:10:48,490 --> 00:10:52,690
between tablets and phones and
PCs and laptops and

238
00:10:52,690 --> 00:10:54,620
stuff here, what you actually get is?

239
00:10:54,620 --> 00:10:58,050
Oh yeah, Don's actually pulling
up a picture of it right here.

240
00:10:58,050 --> 00:11:00,870
And you see that there's different
ones that you can see here.

241
00:11:00,870 --> 00:11:04,150
So here again,
if you're texting and you- Yeah.

242
00:11:04,150 --> 00:11:07,260
Got that and there it is,
the sideways sad frowny face.

243
00:11:07,260 --> 00:11:08,175
There you go.

244
00:11:08,175 --> 00:11:12,614
Yup, and so this screen is designed
to invoke peaceful feelings.

245
00:11:12,614 --> 00:11:13,267
That's right.

246
00:11:13,267 --> 00:11:13,920
You're right.

247
00:11:13,920 --> 00:11:14,630
[LAUGH] Yeah.

248
00:11:14,630 --> 00:11:16,794
And it does give you
a little bit of information.

249
00:11:16,794 --> 00:11:18,410
Yeah.
You'll see right here it says,

250
00:11:18,410 --> 00:11:20,943
if you'd like to know more,
search online for this error.

251
00:11:20,943 --> 00:11:22,190
Yeah.
And here's the error they got.

252
00:11:22,190 --> 00:11:23,980
Always look on the bright side of life.

253
00:11:23,980 --> 00:11:26,860
They probably wrote
a function to cause this,

254
00:11:26,860 --> 00:11:28,483
cuz that doesn't sound
like a common error to me.

255
00:11:28,483 --> 00:11:32,259
[LAUGH] And it'll normally
say something like IRQ- Yeah.

256
00:11:32,259 --> 00:11:33,720
Non-equal or less.

257
00:11:33,720 --> 00:11:36,530
Something like that,
indicating a hardware failure.

258
00:11:36,530 --> 00:11:39,330
It doesn't give you a ton of information.

259
00:11:39,330 --> 00:11:40,810
But that doesn't mean
it isn't gathering it.

260
00:11:40,810 --> 00:11:44,650
What it's doing is in the background,
it's actually recording- Right.

261
00:11:44,650 --> 00:11:45,635
A memory dump.

262
00:11:45,635 --> 00:11:49,695
It's writing to the hard drive stuff
that was in RAM at the time of failure.

263
00:11:49,695 --> 00:11:54,475
And that way when you reboot, if you're
one of those people that can actually deal

264
00:11:54,475 --> 00:11:57,175
with this data,
you can use that file to recover.

265
00:11:57,175 --> 00:11:59,890
All right, now I was a big OS/2- Right.

266
00:11:59,890 --> 00:12:00,756
User back in the day.

267
00:12:00,756 --> 00:12:03,400
IBM OS/2- [LAUGH] I love
that operating system.

268
00:12:03,400 --> 00:12:05,200
And it's all but dead now.

269
00:12:05,200 --> 00:12:12,480
And I remember, gosh this would've been
1995- [LAUGH] Probably, maybe 1996.

270
00:12:12,480 --> 00:12:17,790
I was running OS/2 Warp, and my sound
card caused a segment fault of some sort.

271
00:12:17,790 --> 00:12:19,784
And I got one of those memory
dumps on the screen- Right.

272
00:12:19,784 --> 00:12:21,350
And it gave me all the hexadecimal.

273
00:12:21,350 --> 00:12:23,343
And I called IBM support, cuz I was- Yup.

274
00:12:23,343 --> 00:12:25,020
Under support with them.

275
00:12:25,020 --> 00:12:27,220
And that the operator
on the other hand said,

276
00:12:27,220 --> 00:12:30,230
okay I need you to read
out the memory dump to me.

277
00:12:30,230 --> 00:12:32,273
[LAUGH] And I sat there on the phone and

278
00:12:32,273 --> 00:12:35,144
read out every little
numerical value to this guy.

279
00:12:35,144 --> 00:12:36,309
So that he could- Right.

280
00:12:36,309 --> 00:12:39,750
Punch it into their system and
find out where the fault was.

281
00:12:39,750 --> 00:12:41,470
Well, that was a horrible.

282
00:12:41,470 --> 00:12:42,750
I mean,
I was on the phone with that guy for

283
00:12:42,750 --> 00:12:45,780
well over an hour just reading
off that stuff, it was terrible.

284
00:12:45,780 --> 00:12:47,450
Well, in Windows we don't
have to deal with that.

285
00:12:47,450 --> 00:12:50,790
The memory is actually being
dumped to your hard drive.

286
00:12:50,790 --> 00:12:53,400
And so when we reboot,
we'll get to see this a little bit later.

287
00:12:53,400 --> 00:12:57,290
We actually have software tools that we
can use to open up that dump file, and

288
00:12:57,290 --> 00:13:00,580
do analysis on it and
find out all sorts of good data,

289
00:13:00,580 --> 00:13:04,020
without having to record a bunch of
hexadecimal values from our screen.

290
00:13:04,020 --> 00:13:04,520
Yeah.

291
00:13:05,850 --> 00:13:07,950
All right, so these types of things,

292
00:13:07,950 --> 00:13:11,650
they're called stop errors because
basically your whole system stops.

293
00:13:11,650 --> 00:13:14,810
You've had a crash,
the computer cannot recover from it.

294
00:13:14,810 --> 00:13:16,135
And you're gonna have to reboot.

295
00:13:16,135 --> 00:13:17,170
Yeah.

296
00:13:17,170 --> 00:13:21,230
Now, if you're a regular user, there's
not all that much you can do to recover

297
00:13:21,230 --> 00:13:22,705
from stop errors like these, right?

298
00:13:22,705 --> 00:13:25,112
Right.
Your system is dead in the water and

299
00:13:25,112 --> 00:13:26,551
that's it.

300
00:13:26,551 --> 00:13:27,238
Yeah.

301
00:13:27,238 --> 00:13:30,160
Now, there are some light
things we can do, and

302
00:13:30,160 --> 00:13:32,080
we'll get into the detail
things a little bit later.

303
00:13:32,080 --> 00:13:36,510
But on the higher level we can use
tools like the reliability monitor,

304
00:13:36,510 --> 00:13:37,780
this guy here.

305
00:13:37,780 --> 00:13:42,730
And it can help us to establish whether or
not there's a pattern to these crashes.

306
00:13:42,730 --> 00:13:45,810
Are they always recurring on
the same day at the same time.

307
00:13:45,810 --> 00:13:48,480
Yeah.
Or am I running the same application when

308
00:13:48,480 --> 00:13:49,550
it happens.

309
00:13:49,550 --> 00:13:52,800
Figuring out the pattern is
normally a lot more useful to

310
00:13:52,800 --> 00:13:55,750
finding the cause than it is
analyzing some memory BAM.

311
00:13:55,750 --> 00:13:59,240
Yeah, the Reliability Monitor for
us has been around for a little while.

312
00:13:59,240 --> 00:14:02,970
It actually first made its appearance like
in Vista, and then through Windows 7.

313
00:14:02,970 --> 00:14:06,480
But now Windows 8 it also continues
to make its appearance again.

314
00:14:06,480 --> 00:14:09,310
And it really does track whether
maybe a hardware failure,

315
00:14:09,310 --> 00:14:13,300
a particular software application failure
or whether it's Windows failures as well.

316
00:14:13,300 --> 00:14:15,110
And it does it again tracking over time.

317
00:14:15,110 --> 00:14:19,460
And it gives us a nice little
chart in what we have here.

318
00:14:19,460 --> 00:14:21,780
And so Don has brought up one for
your computer.

319
00:14:21,780 --> 00:14:23,490
This is my laptop- Yup.

320
00:14:23,490 --> 00:14:27,070
And actually,
it looks like I've been doing okay lately.

321
00:14:27,070 --> 00:14:27,650
Yeah.

322
00:14:27,650 --> 00:14:29,770
The reliability monitor this is it, and

323
00:14:29,770 --> 00:14:32,210
you can get at it through
your control panel.

324
00:14:32,210 --> 00:14:33,633
Again, I just use the start screen- Yeah.

325
00:14:33,633 --> 00:14:34,380
And type reliability.

326
00:14:34,380 --> 00:14:35,770
It's the only thing that turns up.

327
00:14:35,770 --> 00:14:38,390
But it's inside of the control panel,
in System and

328
00:14:38,390 --> 00:14:42,770
Security inside the actions center,
and then the reliability monitor.

329
00:14:42,770 --> 00:14:44,700
Right.
So that's how you drill down to find this.

330
00:14:44,700 --> 00:14:46,513
And what it does?

331
00:14:46,513 --> 00:14:51,121
Is it keeps track of what your system has
been doing, and how it's been running?

332
00:14:51,121 --> 00:14:55,799
And it gives you a,
they call it the Reliability Index.

333
00:14:55,799 --> 00:14:56,451
Right.

334
00:14:56,451 --> 00:15:00,840
And they basically rank your computer on a
scale of one to ten by how reliable it is.

335
00:15:00,840 --> 00:15:04,310
Ten is perfectly reliable,
you are a stable system.

336
00:15:04,310 --> 00:15:07,430
One means you are segfaulting-
[LAUGH] All over the place and

337
00:15:07,430 --> 00:15:10,000
you can barely keep your computer online,
all right?

338
00:15:10,000 --> 00:15:12,520
And the last time I pulled
this up in a show- [LAUGH]

339
00:15:12,520 --> 00:15:16,420
I had been crashing a driver repeatedly
and so my numbers were terrible.

340
00:15:16,420 --> 00:15:17,620
Oh Ronnie, yours are terrible.

341
00:15:17,620 --> 00:15:18,545
Yeah.
Jeez, let's pull up your laptop.

342
00:15:18,545 --> 00:15:19,402
Let's do that.
Holy moly.

343
00:15:19,402 --> 00:15:20,650
What are you doing over there?

344
00:15:20,650 --> 00:15:21,190
OneDrive.

345
00:15:21,190 --> 00:15:21,736
So it's all.

346
00:15:21,736 --> 00:15:24,417
[LAUGH] There you go.

347
00:15:24,417 --> 00:15:27,620
All right, so notice that ten would
be all the way up at the top.

348
00:15:27,620 --> 00:15:31,054
It doesn't look like Ronnie has ever hit
a ten- [LAUGH] Where as mine was kinda

349
00:15:31,054 --> 00:15:33,300
cruising at ten this whole time.

350
00:15:33,300 --> 00:15:34,423
But you'll see- Yeah.

351
00:15:34,423 --> 00:15:36,277
Ronnie, you were averaging like a five.

352
00:15:36,277 --> 00:15:37,100
[LAUGH] Yeah, I know.

353
00:15:38,780 --> 00:15:43,120
So the cool thing about
the Reliability Monitor

354
00:15:43,120 --> 00:15:46,520
is it keeps track of when
you install software?

355
00:15:46,520 --> 00:15:48,400
When you install drivers?

356
00:15:48,400 --> 00:15:51,161
When you have errors in the event log?

357
00:15:51,161 --> 00:15:53,866
And it keeps track of what
day in time they occurred on?

358
00:15:53,866 --> 00:15:56,511
So Ronnie can pick a day like
that was a bad day- Yeah.

359
00:15:56,511 --> 00:15:57,716
For you, Ronnie.
Right.

360
00:15:57,716 --> 00:15:59,908
April 12th, that was a week ago.

361
00:15:59,908 --> 00:16:02,021
So, a week ago,
Ronnie had a really bad day.

362
00:16:02,021 --> 00:16:04,651
Yes.
And if he clicks on it like he's done,

363
00:16:04,651 --> 00:16:09,434
down at the bottom it shows what happens
and it looks like Oracle VirtualBox was

364
00:16:09,434 --> 00:16:12,150
just dying [LAUGH] Left and
right Left and right.

365
00:16:12,150 --> 00:16:13,370
Yeah, every ten minutes or so.

366
00:16:13,370 --> 00:16:14,330
What were you doing?

367
00:16:14,330 --> 00:16:15,990
I don't know [LAUGH].

368
00:16:15,990 --> 00:16:16,950
Whatever it was, it was bad.

369
00:16:16,950 --> 00:16:18,930
It was terrible that day.

370
00:16:18,930 --> 00:16:21,860
You also have an Internet Explorer
crash in there.

371
00:16:21,860 --> 00:16:25,490
And so its got these, and if I remember
right Ronnie can double-click on those?

372
00:16:25,490 --> 00:16:26,614
Yep.
Doesn't it open the?

373
00:16:26,614 --> 00:16:30,390
There's a, let's see if it does,
yep there it goes.

374
00:16:30,390 --> 00:16:30,910
Yeah.
So

375
00:16:30,910 --> 00:16:35,470
if you double-click on it you get detailed
information about what that error was and

376
00:16:35,470 --> 00:16:37,450
what was going on when it happened.

377
00:16:37,450 --> 00:16:41,390
So here we see the APPCRASH,
this is for Internet Explorer.

378
00:16:41,390 --> 00:16:45,370
And it gives us information about
what library was being called, and

379
00:16:45,370 --> 00:16:48,390
you'll see what time it was,
what version of Internet Explorer.

380
00:16:48,390 --> 00:16:51,960
Some of the basic information we can
use to try and figure out our issue or

381
00:16:51,960 --> 00:16:53,230
our problem.

382
00:16:53,230 --> 00:16:55,919
This one, not terribly helpful,
ieframe.dll.

383
00:16:55,919 --> 00:16:58,650
[LAUGH] I had some kinda webpage crash.

384
00:16:58,650 --> 00:17:01,800
Usually an extension or
something like that's involved.

385
00:17:01,800 --> 00:17:03,070
If you scroll down a little bit,

386
00:17:03,070 --> 00:17:06,200
you'll see where it tells about
some of the memory dumps it made.

387
00:17:06,200 --> 00:17:08,190
So files that help describe the problem.

388
00:17:08,190 --> 00:17:10,010
If we go and
look at some of these dump files,

389
00:17:10,010 --> 00:17:11,810
we can find out that
additional information.

390
00:17:13,600 --> 00:17:14,330
All right.

391
00:17:14,330 --> 00:17:17,543
The other thing you can use,
though, when you're looking

392
00:17:17,543 --> 00:17:21,169
at this overall kinda calendar view
is you can get an idea- Sorry.

393
00:17:21,169 --> 00:17:23,947
You can get an idea of the pattern,
the timing,

394
00:17:23,947 --> 00:17:28,460
is there a recurring issue that's
happening over and over and over again?

395
00:17:28,460 --> 00:17:34,430
So like we jump back to Ronnie's that
he has some bad stuff happening,

396
00:17:34,430 --> 00:17:36,600
but it's not really fitting a pattern.

397
00:17:36,600 --> 00:17:39,750
And so if you look at it,
like there is SkyDrive crashing.

398
00:17:40,800 --> 00:17:43,070
SkyDrive.
And you'll see more SkyDrive.

399
00:17:43,070 --> 00:17:44,450
You do have a bad history with.

400
00:17:44,450 --> 00:17:45,040
I do.
I mean, OneDrive,

401
00:17:45,040 --> 00:17:46,360
whatever everyone's calling it these days.

402
00:17:48,310 --> 00:17:50,720
So it really helps to
kinda dial in on that.

403
00:17:50,720 --> 00:17:53,600
Again, you don't need to be a programmer
or a developer, you don't need to be

404
00:17:53,600 --> 00:17:58,150
an electrical engineer to just be able to
look and sense patterns and find problems.

405
00:17:58,150 --> 00:18:01,440
What you hope to see is,
notice the bottom part of Ronnie's screen.

406
00:18:01,440 --> 00:18:04,640
He's got a failure, OneDrive Sync
Engine Host has stop working, and

407
00:18:04,640 --> 00:18:08,080
then beneath that there was a definition
update for Windows Defender.

408
00:18:08,080 --> 00:18:11,740
Okay, could it be that the definition
update led to the crash?

409
00:18:11,740 --> 00:18:13,680
No, not in this case because,
look at the time.

410
00:18:13,680 --> 00:18:17,680
The definition update
happened after the crash.

411
00:18:17,680 --> 00:18:21,310
But if you see a driver update
immediately followed by a crash,

412
00:18:21,310 --> 00:18:24,170
then maybe the driver update
is what caused our problem.

413
00:18:24,170 --> 00:18:26,900
And we can roll back that driver and
try and fix it, right?

414
00:18:26,900 --> 00:18:28,850
Right.
So it's a very useful tool.

415
00:18:30,910 --> 00:18:33,990
I like the visual representation
that it gives us down here

416
00:18:33,990 --> 00:18:36,750
on the bottom half of this timeline.

417
00:18:36,750 --> 00:18:40,900
Where it tells you whether it's actually
application related, or Window related, or

418
00:18:40,900 --> 00:18:43,630
again, just the idea of
warnings that come about.

419
00:18:43,630 --> 00:18:46,360
Again, a good idea, once again,
when we track those patterns and

420
00:18:46,360 --> 00:18:49,770
then maybe we could pinpoint, hey there's
something that we need to do here.

421
00:18:49,770 --> 00:18:53,480
Now, I've been dealing with this
OneDrive thing, because where I live,

422
00:18:53,480 --> 00:18:56,530
with the satellite connection,
it's always constantly trying to update.

423
00:18:56,530 --> 00:18:58,814
So I've tried to disable it and so

424
00:18:58,814 --> 00:19:03,880
it's been popping up every time I come
back on our business network here.

425
00:19:03,880 --> 00:19:07,020
[LAUGH] Yeah, so it's probably not happy.

426
00:19:07,020 --> 00:19:10,090
All right, so when it comes to
troubleshooting hardware on our system,

427
00:19:10,090 --> 00:19:13,240
the device manager is a great
place to go to get information.

428
00:19:13,240 --> 00:19:16,860
The reliability monitor,
another great place to go.

429
00:19:16,860 --> 00:19:19,180
There is one particular type of hardware,
though,

430
00:19:19,180 --> 00:19:21,410
that won't be represented
well on those screens.

431
00:19:21,410 --> 00:19:23,210
And that's printers.

432
00:19:23,210 --> 00:19:24,841
Printers, for the most part,

433
00:19:24,841 --> 00:19:28,247
they really don't register their
errors with device manager.

434
00:19:28,247 --> 00:19:31,780
They don't register their errors
with the reliability monitor.

435
00:19:31,780 --> 00:19:36,190
But instead, they register their
errors with the print queues.

436
00:19:36,190 --> 00:19:39,120
And so we can find information
about them in the event logs.

437
00:19:39,120 --> 00:19:41,390
But normally,
when I'm troubleshooting a printer,

438
00:19:41,390 --> 00:19:44,300
it's the print queues that I go to,
right off the bat.

439
00:19:44,300 --> 00:19:45,650
So let me show you an example of that.

440
00:19:45,650 --> 00:19:47,680
I'm going to bring up,
on my machine, here.

441
00:19:47,680 --> 00:19:50,610
Let me just get into my Devices and
Printers.

442
00:19:52,290 --> 00:19:55,990
And we'll see a list of the various
printers that I've got available.

443
00:19:55,990 --> 00:19:58,410
And let's take,
we'll take this guy here, I don't know,

444
00:19:58,410 --> 00:20:01,130
I guess I could really do any of these.

445
00:20:01,130 --> 00:20:04,620
This is a big office printer that
we have here in the building.

446
00:20:04,620 --> 00:20:07,050
And let's say that I'm
sending print jobs to it, and

447
00:20:07,050 --> 00:20:09,156
they're just not coming
out on the other end.

448
00:20:09,156 --> 00:20:10,065
All right.

449
00:20:10,065 --> 00:20:12,905
Well, one of the easiest ways to
find out what's going on is to view

450
00:20:12,905 --> 00:20:13,625
our print queue.

451
00:20:13,625 --> 00:20:16,900
Now, printers have more than
one way of looking at them.

452
00:20:16,900 --> 00:20:20,995
If we right-click, let me zoom in on this,
if we right-click on that menu,

453
00:20:20,995 --> 00:20:21,905
you'll see a few things.

454
00:20:21,905 --> 00:20:25,670
And it gets really confusing because
we've got Printing preferences,

455
00:20:25,670 --> 00:20:30,110
Printer properties and
regular Properties, which one do we go to?

456
00:20:30,110 --> 00:20:34,060
And then we got the Troubleshooter, which
I'm not a big fan of, but it is there.

457
00:20:34,060 --> 00:20:35,500
So which one do we go to?

458
00:20:35,500 --> 00:20:38,730
Well each one gives us
different bits of information.

459
00:20:38,730 --> 00:20:42,150
So for example, if I just choose that
bottom one that says, Properties.

460
00:20:42,150 --> 00:20:47,190
What I'm going to see here is really
information about the hardware, but

461
00:20:47,190 --> 00:20:48,910
not much that I can change.

462
00:20:48,910 --> 00:20:49,630
Right?

463
00:20:49,630 --> 00:20:54,280
This is a Canon imageRUNNER printer,
I can see that, great, now we know.

464
00:20:54,280 --> 00:20:59,590
And if I go over to hardware, I can see
that I've got that printer defined.

465
00:20:59,590 --> 00:21:03,150
It is a printer queue,
we queue up jobs to send to it.

466
00:21:03,150 --> 00:21:06,000
And that's really about it, right?

467
00:21:06,000 --> 00:21:07,450
If I go into my Properties here.

468
00:21:07,450 --> 00:21:11,030
This is where I can drive in and start to
deal with some of the other settings, and

469
00:21:11,030 --> 00:21:13,020
even the driver to an extent.

470
00:21:13,020 --> 00:21:17,320
But you're just not seeing a whole lot
in here to be able to work with, right?

471
00:21:18,380 --> 00:21:23,590
Where we really want to go is if we
right-click on this one and go to Printer

472
00:21:23,590 --> 00:21:28,420
properties, that's the screen where we
really get the ability to change things.

473
00:21:28,420 --> 00:21:32,140
Let me zoom out,
this one doesn't quite fit on the screen.

474
00:21:32,140 --> 00:21:36,100
But in here, we can start to mess
with our preferences if we need to.

475
00:21:36,100 --> 00:21:41,050
But you'll also see under Advanced, here's
where we can manipulate that driver.

476
00:21:41,050 --> 00:21:44,230
You might have more than one driver for
the same printer,

477
00:21:44,230 --> 00:21:46,310
depending on if you've done updates or
whatever.

478
00:21:46,310 --> 00:21:48,390
You can load new drivers here,

479
00:21:48,390 --> 00:21:52,555
this is where we can kinda work
with those driver type issues.

00:21:52,555 --> 00:21:55,680
All right, other things though,

If you just double-click on one of these,
it'll take you in here and

what we're looking at is, basically,
the printer as Windows sees it.

00:22:04,750 --> 00:22:08,370

the support and service, to be able

00:22:12,030 --> 00:22:15,580

486
00:22:15,580 --> 00:22:19,040
If I click on that,
that's gonna bring up the printer queue.

487
00:22:19,040 --> 00:22:23,400
Now, the printer queue has
a couple very simple traits.

488
00:22:23,400 --> 00:22:26,380
One of the most important ones
is the status bar right here,

489
00:22:26,380 --> 00:22:27,360
my status bar is blank.

490
00:22:28,530 --> 00:22:32,190
If I was sending a print job to this
printer, it wouldn't be blank down there.

491
00:22:32,190 --> 00:22:35,920
It would actually say processing,
or printing, or whatever.

492
00:22:36,960 --> 00:22:42,140
If my print job gets stuck,
it would say error right there and

493
00:22:42,140 --> 00:22:44,650
explain why,
it would tell me why I'm getting an error.

494
00:22:44,650 --> 00:22:46,140
All right.

495
00:22:46,140 --> 00:22:48,780
You can also see a print status of paused.

496
00:22:48,780 --> 00:22:52,255
If another administrator somewhere
out there has paused the printer.

497
00:22:52,255 --> 00:22:53,880
Now, why would we pause the printer?

498
00:22:53,880 --> 00:22:55,510
Well, maybe there's a paper jam.

499
00:22:55,510 --> 00:22:58,500
And so we don't want people to try and
print to the printer.

500
00:22:58,500 --> 00:23:03,410
So as an administrator, I might choose
to go to Printer > Pause Printing.

501
00:23:03,410 --> 00:23:06,630
And that way other people can send
print jobs to the printer and

502
00:23:06,630 --> 00:23:08,150
it will just hold onto them.

503
00:23:08,150 --> 00:23:11,710
I can fix the print jam, and
then once the printer is ready to go,

504
00:23:11,710 --> 00:23:16,400
I can unpause the printer and it will
start printing again all on its own.

505
00:23:16,400 --> 00:23:16,972
Okay.

506
00:23:16,972 --> 00:23:19,430
So sorta a great way to go about that.

507
00:23:19,430 --> 00:23:20,140
All right?

508
00:23:20,140 --> 00:23:21,080
But let's say there's an error.

00:23:21,080 --> 00:23:22,791
Let me show you guys an error.

510
00:23:22,791 --> 00:23:23,336
Whoops.

00:23:23,336 --> 00:23:26,174
Let me draw on my screen apparently.

00:23:26,174 --> 00:23:31,940
I'm going to take the printer and
how can I make this one error?

513
00:23:31,940 --> 00:23:35,020
You know what, I'll change the port.

00:23:37,440 --> 00:23:39,930
So right now that
printer's at a certain IP.

00:23:39,930 --> 00:23:43,038
I'm going to add just an incorrect IP.

516
00:23:50,547 --> 00:23:53,128
All right, so I'm gonna add an IP
address that I know is wrong,

00:23:53,128 --> 00:23:54,608
that there's no printer on there.

518
00:23:54,608 --> 00:23:57,778
And I'll tie it to that So when I send

519
00:23:57,778 --> 00:24:00,376
It's gonna try and
send it to that IP that's incorrect and

520
00:24:00,376 --> 00:24:03,330
it's not gonna be able
to contact that printer.

521
00:24:03,330 --> 00:24:07,610
The job is gonna error out and when it
errors out, it'll give me some basic

522
00:24:07,610 --> 00:24:13,480
information about why it errored out and
we can kinda troubleshoot it from there.

523
00:24:13,480 --> 00:24:17,120
In this case, it'll just be the IP that's
wrong but it could be other things.

524
00:24:17,120 --> 00:24:19,060
The printer could be turned off.

525
00:24:19,060 --> 00:24:23,060
I could not have a network connection,
can I even ping the printer?

526
00:24:23,060 --> 00:24:25,910
That's always a good test,
just to see whether that's possible.

527
00:24:25,910 --> 00:24:29,150
So these are all things that we can do
as part of that troubleshooting process

528
00:24:29,150 --> 00:24:30,150
for printers.

529
00:24:30,150 --> 00:24:33,360
You know it's amazing, I'm glad that
you mentioned that cuz sometimes,

00:24:33,360 --> 00:24:35,380
it's very easy to think
that everything is,

534
00:24:44,179 --> 00:24:47,828
trying to reach a piece of paper in
the back of it, disconnecting the power or

535
00:24:47,828 --> 00:24:50,060
even the network cable
a lot of times here.

536
00:24:50,060 --> 00:24:52,830
Having to go back and
just do the simple troubleshooting things

537
00:24:52,830 --> 00:24:56,400
are always good when you're

00:24:56,400 --> 00:24:58,830
So it really does help
in that instance here.

All right, so I'm just gonna lie

00:25:02,940 --> 00:25:03,540
Of course.
Yeah.

00:25:03,540 --> 00:25:04,910
I like to lie to my computer when I can.

00:25:04,910 --> 00:25:06,260
All right, so here we go.

00:25:06,260 --> 00:25:10,110
I'm gonna punch it over to this

544
00:25:10,110 --> 00:25:13,702
There we go and here,
I'll just print this.

545
00:25:18,078 --> 00:25:22,703
You know another thing worth
mentioning is sometimes you'll send

546
00:25:22,703 --> 00:25:25,295
a document to a printer or whatever.

547
00:25:25,295 --> 00:25:25,850
Mm-hm.

548
00:25:25,850 --> 00:25:28,020
And if you've got a corrupted driver.

549
00:25:28,020 --> 00:25:28,730
Yeah.
Or

550
00:25:28,730 --> 00:25:32,150
the printer somehow garbles
the communications or whatever,

551
00:25:32,150 --> 00:25:37,110
you can end up with a print job
that is stuck in the printer, okay?

552
00:25:37,110 --> 00:25:40,940
It'll have an error status sitting
on it and it's just stuck and

553
00:25:40,940 --> 00:25:42,080
you can't get rid of it.

554
00:25:42,080 --> 00:25:46,540
And by get rid of it I mean if you have a
print job lock up, you can normally right

555
00:25:46,540 --> 00:25:50,240
click on it and choose Cancel and
the print job will go away.

556
00:25:50,240 --> 00:25:54,280
But if it gets stuck, if it says error and
hitting cancel doesn't remove it,

557
00:25:54,280 --> 00:25:58,315
it's just stuck there, every other print
job is just gonna build up behind it and

558
00:25:58,315 --> 00:25:59,822
you've effectively blocked your printer.

559
00:26:00,880 --> 00:26:02,320
When that happens,

560
00:26:02,320 --> 00:26:08,350
a corrupted print job is very difficult to
clear out just through our regular GUI.

561
00:26:08,350 --> 00:26:12,620
All the print jobs are being managed by
a service called the print spooler and

562
00:26:12,620 --> 00:26:17,430
the print spooler holds all those
print jobs open and so if you try and

563
00:26:17,430 --> 00:26:21,330
cancel it or manually delete it, you can't
because they're being manually held open.

564
00:26:21,330 --> 00:26:23,460
So if you ever have a print
job that gets stuck,

565
00:26:23,460 --> 00:26:28,400
one of the easiest solutions is to simply
restart your print spooler, all right?

566
00:26:28,400 --> 00:26:31,530
And while I wait on this one to error
out because it's doing its retries,

567
00:26:31,530 --> 00:26:36,150
let me show you, I'm just gonna
bring up my services screen and

568
00:26:36,150 --> 00:26:38,760
I'll hunt down the print spooler.

569
00:26:38,760 --> 00:26:40,310
Yep, there's my error.

570
00:26:40,310 --> 00:26:45,368
Here's the print spooler right here, and I
could right click on the print spooler and

571
00:26:45,368 --> 00:26:46,920
choose Restart Service.

572
00:26:46,920 --> 00:26:50,870
When it restarts,
any corrupted print jobs will get deleted

573
00:26:50,870 --> 00:26:55,020
out cuz when the service stops,
that releases the hold on those files and

574
00:26:55,020 --> 00:26:58,400
then when it starts back up it tries to
read the files, sees the corruption and

575
00:26:58,400 --> 00:26:59,800
just deletes them, all right?

576
00:26:59,800 --> 00:27:02,770
So a very, very simple way.

577
00:27:02,770 --> 00:27:04,450
Yeah.
In fact, back in NT4 days, I got my NCSC,

578
00:27:04,450 --> 00:27:05,320
Did it all the time, yeah.

579
00:27:05,320 --> 00:27:07,580
Originally under NT4 and
this was in the book.

580
00:27:07,580 --> 00:27:08,235
Yeah.
It was like hey,

581
00:27:08,235 --> 00:27:09,440
restart your print spooler.

582
00:27:09,440 --> 00:27:10,850
Yeah.
Now they don't mention it so much but

583
00:27:10,850 --> 00:27:11,955
it's still very, very valid.

584
00:27:11,955 --> 00:27:12,801
Mm-hm.
All right,

585
00:27:12,801 --> 00:27:17,340
let's go take a look
at my error All right.

586
00:27:17,340 --> 00:27:20,250
So here's my print job and
I do have an error now.

00:27:20,250 --> 00:27:23,470
See how it says Error-Printing and

00:27:23,470 --> 00:27:26,000
I've got one document in
queue in my note there.

So, I know there's been an error,
all right?

00:27:29,170 --> 00:27:31,790
But it's not really giving me
a ton of information, is it?

591
00:27:32,950 --> 00:27:37,660
Aside from the fact that there is
an error, if I pull up the properties,

00:27:37,660 --> 00:27:42,870
you really just get basic information
about the print job itself and so it's not

593
00:27:42,870 --> 00:27:47,745
really giving me a ton of data as to why
that error happened in the first place.

594
00:27:47,745 --> 00:27:48,450
Mm-hm.
So

00:27:48,450 --> 00:27:50,670
I'm somewhat limited in my choices here.

00:27:50,670 --> 00:27:53,510
I can try and restart the print job.

Right click on it, choose Restart,

00:27:56,630 --> 00:28:01,280
if that doesn't work, I need to see if I

599
00:28:01,280 --> 00:28:06,130
If you can't, a lot of times,
in the devices and printers screen,

600
00:28:06,130 --> 00:28:07,440
which I guess I closed.

601
00:28:07,440 --> 00:28:08,598
Thought I still had that open somewhere.

00:28:08,598 --> 00:28:09,696
[LAUGH] Guess not.

00:28:12,106 --> 00:28:15,457
In the devices and printer screen,
if you can't communicate with the printer,

00:28:15,457 --> 00:28:18,860
a lot of times it will be grayed out but
you will see mine is not grayed out.

605
00:28:18,860 --> 00:28:22,890
But if I float over it, I do see a status
error right there, letting me know

606

there is some kind of problem with
the printer and I can see that error here.

00:28:26,980 --> 00:28:30,140
I just double-clicked on the printer and
if I click on error,

608
00:28:30,140 --> 00:28:30,900
it just takes you in here.

609
00:28:30,900 --> 00:28:33,460
So you're not really seeing
a ton of details but

610
00:28:33,460 --> 00:28:36,790
you can try and ping the printer,
see if you can get there.

611
00:28:36,790 --> 00:28:39,760
Run a test page, right?

612
00:28:39,760 --> 00:28:41,940
Test pages are pretty easy to send.

00:28:41,940 --> 00:28:43,690
Let's see if I can remember where that is.

614
00:28:43,690 --> 00:28:46,960
If we go back into our,
I just closed that screen again.

615
00:28:46,960 --> 00:28:48,330
See how many times I can do that.

00:28:49,670 --> 00:28:52,430
We right click on the printer and
go to Printer Properties.

00:28:52,430 --> 00:28:55,680
They'd be down there at

00:28:57,010 --> 00:28:59,120
Yeah, it's right there at the bottom,
Print Test Page.

00:28:59,120 --> 00:29:01,700
So we can hit that, and
it will send a standard Windows test page.

620
00:29:01,700 --> 00:29:05,130
That'll take your software out of
the equation, and let you see whether or

621
00:29:05,130 --> 00:29:07,685
not it's a driver or
hardware issue from there.

622
00:29:07,685 --> 00:29:09,910
So there's some good tools here.

623
00:29:09,910 --> 00:29:13,870
Not the most detailed of information but
the thing about the printers is, today,

624
00:29:13,870 --> 00:29:15,110
a lot of them are networked printers.

625
00:29:15,110 --> 00:29:17,010
They're not directly
attached to your machine and

626
00:29:17,010 --> 00:29:19,600
that's why we don't get error reporting
in the device manager, for example.

627
00:29:21,250 --> 00:29:24,170
Now, this brings us up to that one
topic we were kind of like what do

628
00:29:24,170 --> 00:29:29,160
we really want to do this,
which is that NFC to print idea.

629
00:29:29,160 --> 00:29:31,690
Near field communication
is really this idea for

630
00:29:31,690 --> 00:29:34,760
us that we can have the devices
that are wireless, and

631
00:29:34,760 --> 00:29:39,980
then simply take the device over to an NFC
aware printer, or one that is enabled for

632
00:29:39,980 --> 00:29:44,510
us and tap it, and that'll actually cause
the print job to actually begin printing.

633
00:29:44,510 --> 00:29:45,660
Pretty neat.

634
00:29:45,660 --> 00:29:49,250
And this is really designed for
mobile devices, cell phones, iPads,

635
00:29:49,250 --> 00:29:53,730
whatever, you don't really see
it in laptops but Microsoft,

636
00:29:53,730 --> 00:29:57,330
they're starting to blend the line
between the Windows phones devices and

637
00:29:57,330 --> 00:30:02,230
the surface tablets and stuff and
so, if you have NFC in your laptop,

638
00:30:02,230 --> 00:30:06,430
which we've got fairly new laptops
here and none of ours have it.

639
00:30:06,430 --> 00:30:09,660
So if you have NFC in your laptop and

640
00:30:09,660 --> 00:30:12,730
you have an NFC enabled printer,
you can do Tap To Print.

641
00:30:13,910 --> 00:30:17,640
Basically, you'll have a Tap To Print
application, which if you have an HP

642
00:30:17,640 --> 00:30:22,250
printer, you normally install the HP
application on your laptop or device.

643
00:30:22,250 --> 00:30:25,950
My cell phone has it and I've got
the HP application on my cell phone.

644
00:30:25,950 --> 00:30:30,320
So I can walk up to an HP printer, and I
can fire up that application on my phone,

645
00:30:30,320 --> 00:30:33,690
and hit the Tap To Print and
I touch my phone to the printer.

646
00:30:34,830 --> 00:30:39,590
The NFC tag in the device, it
establishes contact at about six inches,

647
00:30:39,590 --> 00:30:42,740
you really need to get close but
it'll tap it and

648
00:30:42,740 --> 00:30:45,740
basically what it does is it
exchanges an authentication key.

649
00:30:45,740 --> 00:30:48,810
Then the devices are allowed to
talk over the wireless network

650
00:30:48,810 --> 00:30:50,650
to be able to send that print job in.

651
00:30:50,650 --> 00:30:52,460
So you don't actually print via NFC.

652
00:30:52,460 --> 00:30:54,610
NFC's too slow.

653
00:30:54,610 --> 00:30:57,050
You're just exchanging
security credentials so

654
00:30:57,050 --> 00:31:00,220
that you can then communicate,
usually with Wi-Fi Direct or

655
00:31:00,220 --> 00:31:05,040
some other wireless networking
technology that's faster than NFC.

656
00:31:05,040 --> 00:31:05,920
Yeah. All right. I don't know why,

657
00:31:05,920 --> 00:31:09,080
the first time I saw this I envisioned
somebody literally bringing their desktop

658
00:31:09,080 --> 00:31:11,590
computer and
trying to tap it on the printer.

659
00:31:11,590 --> 00:31:13,820
Yeah.
I know that's not the truth but

660
00:31:13,820 --> 00:31:15,760
that's how I envisioned it
the first time and I'm like wow,

661
00:31:15,760 --> 00:31:18,720
that's kind of weird that somebody
would actually need to do that.

662
00:31:18,720 --> 00:31:22,070
Don, have you seen this really
in where you had worked before?

663
00:31:22,070 --> 00:31:23,020
No.

664
00:31:23,020 --> 00:31:28,580
NFC is still a very new technology, and
some of this is gaining acceptance.

665
00:31:28,580 --> 00:31:32,420
Most laptops and desktops don't have
NFC transmitters or receivers in them.

666
00:31:32,420 --> 00:31:33,090
Right.
So,

667
00:31:33,090 --> 00:31:36,460
we're not seeing widespread acceptance of
this yet but on mobile devices, we are.

668
00:31:36,460 --> 00:31:36,990
Yea.

669
00:31:36,990 --> 00:31:40,870
Android phones became popular about a year
ago, and or two years ago, I guess.

670
00:31:40,870 --> 00:31:42,300
Sure.
And even on the iPhone.

671
00:31:42,300 --> 00:31:43,960
Yeah.
You're starting to see NFC, so

672
00:31:43,960 --> 00:31:47,182
it is catching on there because it can be
used for mobile payments and all that.

673
00:31:47,182 --> 00:31:49,786
Yeah.
I've got pulled up, the HP page here.

674
00:31:49,786 --> 00:31:53,730
Their webpage, and
you'll see right here on HP's webpage.

675
00:31:53,730 --> 00:31:56,339
With their multifunction printers,
the MFPs.

676
00:31:56,339 --> 00:32:00,241
They're really pushing that whole
touch to print right here, right?

677
00:32:00,241 --> 00:32:03,740
But even they're showing a cell
phone touching the printer.

678
00:32:03,740 --> 00:32:05,620
Not like your laptop.

679
00:32:05,620 --> 00:32:09,110
So if you got a laptop, expect
the use the wireless printing to it or

680
00:32:09,110 --> 00:32:11,580
whatever, which is really
not that hard to do.

681
00:32:11,580 --> 00:32:14,100
Yeah, so, all right.

682
00:32:14,100 --> 00:32:16,950
So those are some of the things
to think about with printers.

683
00:32:16,950 --> 00:32:19,870
On the NFC side, you don't usually
have a whole lotta errors.

684
00:32:19,870 --> 00:32:21,500
The main problems I've
seen is where people have

685
00:32:21,500 --> 00:32:23,320
disabled their wireless antenna.

686
00:32:23,320 --> 00:32:25,490
And so they've got NFC.

687
00:32:25,490 --> 00:32:29,060
And they tap the printer and the printer
does the tap of print stuff but

688
00:32:29,060 --> 00:32:30,722
then they can't communicate over wireless.

689
00:32:30,722 --> 00:32:33,160
People don't realize that
it doesn't print over NFC.

690
00:32:33,160 --> 00:32:35,330
That's usually the problem that creeps up.

691
00:32:35,330 --> 00:32:38,810
So that's really about it on those.

00:32:38,810 --> 00:32:43,290
The other thing is NFC is just
a communications protocol.

00:32:43,290 --> 00:32:45,220
It doesn't enable you
to talk to the printer,

694
00:32:45,220 --> 00:32:47,360
you do need an application
from that vendor.

00:32:47,360 --> 00:32:50,510
So, with HP,
you need the HP software installed.

00:32:50,510 --> 00:32:55,890
And if you don't have that, then you're
not gonna be able to do the touch.

When these things start happening,

00:34:34,950 --> 00:34:38,330
And what we try to do, of course,

00:34:48,690 --> 00:34:53,060
But there are actually a bunch of

00:34:53,060 --> 00:34:53,980

These are ones that you

00:35:03,230 --> 00:35:04,140

Windows to actually have this.

So let's talk about one

00:35:12,130 --> 00:35:14,960

00:35:14,960 --> 00:35:18,670
The WPT, it's not included with Windows.

00:35:18,670 --> 00:35:20,470
But you go and download it from Microsoft.

00:35:20,470 --> 00:35:22,380
It's free, they don't charge you for it.

753
00:35:22,380 --> 00:35:25,940
But it is a collection of tools and

754
00:35:25,940 --> 00:35:30,200
software that let's you troubleshoot
these weird intermittent problems.

755
00:35:30,200 --> 00:35:32,340
Now these tools are not for
the faint of heart.

756
00:35:32,340 --> 00:35:35,020
They are somewhat complex, right?

00:35:35,020 --> 00:35:38,510
But when you install the WPT,

00:35:38,510 --> 00:35:40,910
You check off the options that

00:35:40,910 --> 00:35:42,770

00:35:42,770 --> 00:35:46,700
But once it's installed you get some

00:35:46,700 --> 00:35:50,190
And that's what Microsoft is calling

762
00:35:50,190 --> 00:35:54,017
Where they're saying optimize performance
using the Windows Performance Toolkit.

763
00:35:54,017 --> 00:35:56,556
And then they go to list a bunch

764
00:35:56,556 --> 00:35:58,500
may not have ever heard of before.

765
00:35:58,500 --> 00:36:01,241
These are all part of the WPT.

Now, there are some

00:36:03,353 --> 00:36:06,825
You'll see Xperf,
X Xbootmgr and XperfView.

768
00:36:06,825 --> 00:36:11,325
Those are for the performance monitor as
well as the boot manager to be able to see

769
00:36:11,325 --> 00:36:14,270

00:36:14,270 --> 00:36:16,920
There's also a graphical user interface,

771
00:36:16,920 --> 00:36:20,860
a GUI which is part of

772
00:36:20,860 --> 00:36:23,290
Analyzer that we're gonna see

773
00:36:24,410 --> 00:36:26,380
You use the command line utilities for

774
00:36:26,380 --> 00:36:29,400
when you're trying to trigger these
things to run like a boot time.

775
00:36:29,400 --> 00:36:31,450
Or, whatever if you're
trying to automate it.

776
00:36:31,450 --> 00:36:34,160
Oh yeah, scripts,
that'd be a perfect example.

777
00:36:34,160 --> 00:36:36,479
The GUI on the other hand is
what we use when we wanna do it.

778
00:36:36,479 --> 00:36:37,364
[LAUGH] Right.

779
00:36:37,364 --> 00:36:40,970
When we actually wanna mostly

00:36:40,970 --> 00:36:42,740
So the way it works is really simple.

00:36:42,740 --> 00:36:47,000
You fire up either Xperf from
the command line to gather data.

00:36:47,000 --> 00:36:49,600

00:36:49,600 --> 00:36:52,690

So we'll see the Windows

What do you wanna record and

00:37:12,250 --> 00:37:13,870

And I've checked a few of

00:37:23,090 --> 00:37:25,800
So I'm running my

00:37:28,140 --> 00:37:29,420
And oh, you remembered my settings.

00:37:29,420 --> 00:37:31,456
Well let me here, I'll just put it back.

00:37:33,940 --> 00:37:39,290
All right, and you'll see that it's

00:37:39,290 --> 00:37:43,760
And first level triage, that's

00:37:43,760 --> 00:37:48,350
It's what your basic performance settings,

00:38:01,370 --> 00:38:05,159
And in each of the different things that

00:38:05,159 --> 00:38:05,830

Now Don, the nice thing is over there on

They've already got some of these

So if you're not sure exactly what you

You can actually run through these instead

Yeah, absolutely.

And you also see like the detail level.

Generally you want verbose, you don't

But then this last one, logging mode.

All right,

If you're gonna be walking away from

All right, when you open up a file made

Now the exam objectives,

They want you to use

Both are included in the Performance

Now, what you do is you basically use

So we can start to see what was

hey, you had a crash, these are the

You know,

01:00:43,970 --> 01:00:47,970
So in our last two segments, we've taken a
look at several troubleshooting utilities,

1332
01:00:47,970 --> 01:00:50,680
and when they're appropriate,
and when we can use them.

1333
01:00:50,680 --> 01:00:54,340
And we made a reference at
the beginning of the show to the crash

1334
01:00:54,340 --> 01:00:58,420
memory dumps that happen when we
get a blue screen on our system.

1335
01:00:58,420 --> 01:01:00,673
And those crash memory dumps,
for the most part,

1336
01:01:00,673 --> 01:01:02,936
are not something that's
terribly useful to us.

1337
01:01:02,936 --> 01:01:07,783
But Microsoft does have a special,
super secret, double-probation utility

1338
01:01:07,783 --> 01:01:12,020
available that allows us to get some
insight into those crash dumps.

1339
01:01:12,020 --> 01:01:16,330
And not only that, but
to get all sorts of other recovery tools.

1340
01:01:16,330 --> 01:01:20,662
And this is all part of what's
called the DaRT, or Disaster and

1341
01:01:20,662 --> 01:01:23,130
Recovery Toolkit from Microsoft.

1342
01:01:23,130 --> 01:01:23,698
Yeah.

1343
01:01:23,698 --> 01:01:26,250
The Disaster and
Recovery Toolkit for us, though,

1344
01:01:26,250 --> 01:01:30,110
it doesn't magically appear in the way
that we would normally need it, okay.

1345
01:01:30,110 --> 01:01:31,970
So it's kind of an unusual tool for

1346
01:01:31,970 --> 01:01:35,160
us, in the very fact that you have
to build this particular tool.

1347
01:01:35,160 --> 01:01:39,350
So a lot of times what you have to do of
course is get all of those tools lined up,

1348
01:01:39,350 --> 01:01:42,650
in other words,
the prerequisites lined up first.

1349
01:01:42,650 --> 01:01:44,790
And then once you get all
that actually installed and

1350
01:01:44,790 --> 01:01:49,050
doing what you need to, then you can build
what we call a disaster recovery media.

1351
01:01:49,050 --> 01:01:53,037
Now, Microsoft and Windows 8.1,
a lot of times before this,

1352
01:01:53,037 --> 01:01:57,673
we only had the idea of an ISO or then a
DVD, or usually a DVD and the size of it,

1353
01:01:57,673 --> 01:02:01,806
that you would actually be able to
burn and then you could take that to

1354
01:02:01,806 --> 01:02:06,800
any particular computer that had a DVD
drive in it, and load it right up.

1355
01:02:06,800 --> 01:02:08,580
But Microsoft, over time,
has actually said, look,

1356
01:02:08,580 --> 01:02:10,930
we can actually include
this in the images today.

1357
01:02:10,930 --> 01:02:13,910
If we want to,
to put it on thumb drives as well, and

1358
01:02:13,910 --> 01:02:16,730
that way you don't have to
worry about just having a DVD.

1359
01:02:16,730 --> 01:02:19,990
And you can even load it up directly.

1360
01:02:19,990 --> 01:02:22,500
Like we said,
if you already have a recovery partition,

1361
01:02:22,500 --> 01:02:25,920
you can actually replace that one and
actually put this in its place instead.

1362
01:02:25,920 --> 01:02:27,950
So I mean, there's a lot of
different features for us here.

1363
01:02:27,950 --> 01:02:29,970
Yeah, the DaRT,

1364
01:02:29,970 --> 01:02:32,980
it originally started out as just
a bootable CD like Ronnie was saying.

1365
01:02:32,980 --> 01:02:36,557
And it just had a bunch of tools, a bunch
of utilities on there that were there to

1366
01:02:36,557 --> 01:02:38,633
help you fix a machine
that no longer worked.

1367
01:02:38,633 --> 01:02:41,940
That wouldn't boot up, that was
blue-screening, that had whatever issues.

1368
01:02:41,940 --> 01:02:44,050
You had this CD packed full of utilities.

1369
01:02:44,050 --> 01:02:46,260
And over the years,
they've added more and more to it.

1370
01:02:46,260 --> 01:02:49,150
And they keep updating it so
there's different versions of the DaRT.

1371
01:02:49,150 --> 01:02:50,920
And they normally correspond with the OS.

1372
01:02:50,920 --> 01:02:54,760
So, like, right now, there's the DaRT for
Windows 8 and DaRT for Windows 8.1.

1373
01:02:54,760 --> 01:02:56,225
It is that specific.

1374
01:02:56,225 --> 01:02:57,900
So there's different ones
that are available, and

1375
01:02:57,900 --> 01:02:59,087
you need to get the appropriate one.

1376
01:02:59,087 --> 01:03:01,486
Now, Ronnie mentioned,
it doesn't just magically appear.

1377
01:03:01,486 --> 01:03:03,850
Right [LAUGH].
So, let's talk a little bit about that.

1378
01:03:03,850 --> 01:03:07,327
First off, in order to get
the disaster recovery toolkit,

1379
01:03:07,327 --> 01:03:09,274
it's not a standalone product,

1380
01:03:09,274 --> 01:03:14,365
it's a part of what's called the Microsoft
Desktop Optimization Pack, or the MDOP.

1381
01:03:14,365 --> 01:03:20,210
And the MDOP is only available to
enterprise customers of Microsoft.

1382
01:03:20,210 --> 01:03:24,090
If you have a volume license agreement
with Microsoft, you get this for free.

1383
01:03:24,090 --> 01:03:26,800
If you don't have a volume
license agreement with Microsoft,

1384
01:03:26,800 --> 01:03:28,120
you don't get this tool, period.

1385
01:03:28,120 --> 01:03:29,430
That's it.
They don't sell it,

1386
01:03:29,430 --> 01:03:32,600
you can't buy it on their website,
it's not free.

1387
01:03:32,600 --> 01:03:35,020
It's part of, well, it's sort of free.

1388
01:03:35,020 --> 01:03:37,990
After you pay them a ton of money,
you get it for free, right.

1389
01:03:37,990 --> 01:03:39,840
So that's how it works if
you're an enterprise customer.

1390
01:03:39,840 --> 01:03:43,297
So if you're an enterprise,
a big business, if you've got thousands of

1391
01:03:43,297 --> 01:03:47,035
Microsoft machines, if you're a school
board or government, you likely have

1392
01:03:47,035 --> 01:03:50,972
an enterprise agreement with Microsoft,
and the MDOP is free for you, all right.

1393
01:03:50,972 --> 01:03:56,788
If you are like ITProTV where we have
a handful of licenses to suit our staff.

1394
01:03:56,788 --> 01:03:58,633
But not enough to do
an enterprise agreement,

1395
01:03:58,633 --> 01:03:59,968
it becomes not available for us.

1396
01:03:59,968 --> 01:04:00,805
Yeah.

1397
01:04:00,805 --> 01:04:01,687
Now, I'm a Microsoft trainer.

1398
